text: Broadcast regulator Ofcom has thrown out a Tory complaint over Channel 4 NNP ' NN NN debate after Boris Johnson refused to take part . The broadcaster ' empty chaired ' the Tory leader in the debate - and replaced him on screen with an NN sculpture , slowly melting under the studio lights . Ofcom VBD the sculpture was not supposed to " personally " represent Mr Johnson and that little editorial focus was given to the object throughout the debate . The party sent Michael Gove to the studio to offer to stand in for the leader 's debate , but the other leaders taking part in the debate turned him down . He arrived at the studio along with a camera , capturing the stunt for the Tories ' JJ NN outlets . This morning the regulator VBD they had rejected the complaint . A spokesman VBD : " In this NN , the NNP Committee concluded that , across the CD - hour debate and a subsequent NN programme , Channel 4 ’s use of editorial techniques ensured that the Conservative ’s viewpoint on NN and JJ issues was adequately reflected and given due weight . They added : " The Committee RB took into account that the globe NN sculpture was not a representation of the Prime Minister personally , and little editorial focus was given to it , either visually or in references made by the presenter or debate participants " The party made a formal complaint to broadcasting watchdog Ofcom 's NN committee over what it VBD was " a provocative partisan stunt , which MD itself constitute making a JJ opinion in its own NN " . And a Tory source threatened to " reconsider " the broadcaster 's licence over the row . Mr Johnson VBD LBC the following day : " I did n't VB the debate but it is noticeable that NNS have talked more about that than the substance that came out of the debate and I VBP that is a shame . " Answering a question about the Tory threat to review the publicly - owned broadcaster 's licence , he responded : " What we VBP is a free , fair and exuberant , unbridled NN . That 's what I VBP . " I VBP a free press is CD of the glories of our country and I VBP to protect it and enshrine it . " Shadow culture secretary Tom Watson wrote to Ofcom about the matter and VBD it was " deeply concerning that a governing party MD wish to restrict the free press " . In his letter , he VBD : " I 'm urging you to call out this meddling and demand that whichever JJ party wins the next General NN allows Ofcom to operate freely from JJ interference . " We VBP a strong free press , but the Tories are restricting journalists . This campaign , Boris Johnson has banned the Daily Mirror from its battle bus , ducked the Andrew Neil interview and now attempted to bully Channel 4 . " On the day of the debate , presenter Krishnan Guru - Murthy , tweeted : " It was kind of Michael Gove to turn up at Channel 4 NNP tonight offering to come on the NNP Debate but the other party leaders will only debate other party leaders . " We look forward to welcoming Mr Gove another NN . "

text: Every aspect of our lives has been affected by the NN . The JJ economy has slowed , NNS have retreated to their homes and thousands have died or become seriously ill . At this frightening stage of the NN , it ’s difficult to focus on anything else . But as the International Agency has VBN , the effects of NN are likely to be temporary but the other JJ emergency – NN NN – is not . Stopping the spread of NN is paramount , but NN NN must RB continue . And we can draw JJ lessons and opportunities from the current NN NN when tackling planetary NN . S&P NNP Ratings this week VBD measures to contain NNP - CD have pushed the JJ economy into recession . JJ analyst Lauri Myllyvirta estimates the NN MD have reduced JJ NNS by 200 megatonnes of NN dioxide to date , as air travel grinds to a halt , factories close down and NN demand falls . In the JJ four weeks of the NN , coal consumption in NNP alone fell by 36 % , and oil refining capacity reduced by 34 % . In JJ ways , what we ’re seeing now is a rapid and unplanned version of JJ “ degrowth ” – the transition some academics and activists have for decades VBN is necessary to address NN NN , and leave a habitable NN for future generations . Read more : NN in a ' degrowth ' economy , and why you might actually enjoy it Degrowth is a proposed slowing of growth in sectors that damage the environment , such as fossil fuel industries , until the economy operates within NNP ’s limits . It is a voluntary , planned and equitable transition in developed nations which necessarily involves an increased focus on the environment , JJ well - being , and capabilities ( good NN , decent work , education , and a safe and healthy environment ) . Such a transformation MD be profound , and so far no nation has shown the will to implement it . It MD require JJ economies to “ decouple ” from NN to prevent NN - related crises . But the current unintended JJ slowdown opens the door to such a transition , which MD bring myriad benefits to the NN . The idea of sustainable degrowth is very JJ to a recession . It involves scaling back environmentally damaging sectors of the economy , and strengthening others . NN NN has been declared a JJ emergency , yet to date the NN has largely failed to address it . In contrast , the JJ policy response to the NN emergency has been fast and furious . There are several reasons for this dramatic difference . NN NN is a relatively slow - moving NN , whereas NN visibly escalates over days , RB hours , increasing our perception of the risks involved . CD thing that history teaches us about politics and the JJ condition in times of peril , we often take a “ NN management ” approach to dealing with serious threats . Read more : How NNS brought on by NN MD VB tackle NN NN As others have observed , the slow increase in JJ NNS means NNS can psychologically adjust as the situation worsens , making the problem seem less urgent and meaning NNS are less willing to accept drastic policy measures . The JJ response to the NN NN shows that governments can take immediate , radical emergency measures , which VBP beyond purely JJ concerns , to protect the well - being of all . Specifically , there are practical lessons and opportunities we can take away from the NN emergency as we seek to tackle NN NN : Act early : The NN NN shows the crucial importance of early NN to prevent catastrophic consequences . Governments in Taiwan , South Korea and Singapore acted quickly to implement quarantine and screening measures , and have seen relatively JJ numbers of infections . Italy , on the other hand , whose NN waited too RB to act , is now the epicentre of the NN . Read more : Running out of things to do in isolation ? VB back in the garden with these ideas from 4 experts VB slow , VB local : NN has forced an immediate scale - down of how we travel and live . However with JJ distancing expected to be in place for months , our scaled - down lives MD become the “ JJ normal ” . JJ NNS MD realise that consumption and personal well - being are not inextricably linked . JJ JJ thinking is needed . A transition to sustainable degrowth can VB . We VBP to shift JJ attention from GDP as an indicator of well - being , towards other measures that put NNS and the environment RB , such as NNP Zealand ’s well - being budget , Bhutan ’s gross national happiness index , or Ecuador ’s JJ philosophy of buen vivir ( good living ) . Spend on clean NN : The International NNP Agency ( IEA ) VBZ clean NN should be “ at the heart of stimulus plans to counter the NN NN ” . The IEA has called on governments to launch sustainable stimulus packages focused on clean NN technologies . It VBZ hydrogen and NN - capture RB VBP major investment to bring them to scale , which MD be helped by the current low interest rates . Governments MD RB use NN stimulus packages to reskill workers to service the JJ “ green ” economy , and address challenges in healthcare , sanitation , aged care , food security and education . As NN scientist Katharine Hayhoe VBD this month : The NN NN is devastating , but failing to tackle NN NN because of the NN only compounds the tragedy . text: Australia ’s Iconic Platypus Has Been Pushed to the Brink of Extinction , NNPS Warn With Australia ’s spiraling JJ catastrophe receiving NN attention in recent weeks , ecologists have sounded the alarm on the dire threat faced by the country ’s endemic wildlife populations . Researchers are now warning that the platypus — the unusual duck - billed , egg - laying mammal native to eastern Australia whose existence was believed to be a hoax in the late 18th century — is CD of the iconic NNS teetering on the brink of extinction . Along with other contemporary threats including the changing NN , NNS fear that platypus numbers will continue to decline between 47 percent and 66 percent by 2070 . However , when taking fast - heating NN projections into account the animal ’s decline MD rapidly fall by 51 percent to 73 over the next five decades — pushing the NNS once common in the country ’s waterways toward all - out extinction . The danger to platypuses has become alarming in recent consecutive NNS as brutal heatwaves and arid conditions made worse by the dearth of rainfall have had a devastating effect on local populations . Platypus populations , IN other aquatic NNS , are believed to have taken major damage from an intensifying drought and record heat , RB prior to the bushfire NN . To VB it now … a cesspit that ’s bacteria ridden and lifeless … certainly in our area — and this must be so wide spread — they ’re gone . ” With its unique set of physical features , early sketches of the duck - billed mammal shocked western NNS who stumbled on the existence of the platypus during the colonization of Australia . text: In 1916 , Antarctic explorer Ernest Shackleton was forced to make a treacherous voyage across the open waters of the Southern Ocean after his ship Endurance was crushed by pack NN and sank in the Weddell NNP . Along with five members of his party , Shackleton set out for the island of South Georgia in a 23 - NN - JJ wooden lifeboat named the James Caird . Eleven days into the trip , on NNP 5 , Shackleton thought he spied a clearing in the murky sky above . What he was actually seeing was n’t a break in the clouds , but the white crest of a monstrous wave bearing down on them . “ During twenty - six NNS ’ experience of the ocean in all its moods I had not encountered a wave so gigantic , ” Shackleton MD later write in his book South : The Story of Shackleton ’s Last Expedition 1914 - 1917 . “ It was a mighty upheaval of the ocean , a thing quite apart from the JJ white - capped seas that had been our tireless enemies for JJ days . ” Shackleton ’s account remains CD of the most evocative descriptions of the westerly winds that circle the globe between 30 and 60 degrees latitude in both hemispheres and the colossal waves they whip up in the Southern Ocean . Today , the southern westerlies are back in focus for entirely JJ reasons : their potential impact on NN NN . The NN ’s oceans take up more than a quarter of the NN NNS are emitting into the atmosphere , partially mitigating the NN effect of that NN . And the Southern Ocean accounts for nearly 40 percent of this marine NN absorption , RB though it makes up only CD - fifth of NNP ’s ocean NN area . There MD be enormous consequences for our already VBG NN from RB a JJ reduction in the Southern Ocean ’s ability to suck up NN from the atmosphere . NNS VBP this reduction MD already be happening , and they suspect that the westerlies in the Southern Hemisphere , which are stronger than their northern counterparts because they blow mostly over open NN , are to blame . Records of actual wind speeds , as well as estimates of wind speeds from measurements of atmospheric pressure , provide clear signs that the westerlies in both hemispheres are shifting toward the poles and intensifying . NN models show that these NNS are partly due to JJ NN , and research is afoot to determine if they are hindering the Southern Ocean ’s capacity to pull NN out of the atmosphere . “ There are questions about what ’s VBG to happen if the winds continue to VB stronger , ” VBZ paleoclimate scientist Krystyna Saunders of the Australian Nuclear NNP and Technology Organisation in Sydney . “ How much can the oceans actually absorb ? ” Saunders and her colleagues are finding clues that over the past 12,000 NNS of NNP ’s history , higher wind speeds and greater concentrations of NN dioxide in the atmosphere have gone together . If this link between wind and CO ₂ holds JJ today , it will lead to higher levels of the NN gas in the atmosphere , which will speed up NN NN , which MD further intensify the westerlies . There ’s growing NN that , at least in the winter months when the westerlies are at their most violent , some parts of the Southern Ocean are giving off more of the gas than was previously estimated . It has all the makings of a vicious cycle . The westerlies are the result of a JJ atmospheric circulation NN , starting with what is called the Hadley cell . The cell forms as warm , moist air near the equator rises into the upper atmosphere and then , as it cools and dries , much of it sinks down toward NNP at about 30 degrees latitude in each hemisphere . Lower in the atmosphere , this air moves back toward the equator , completing the cell . Some of this downward - moving mass of air escapes the Hadley cell and moves away from the equator , and is deflected by NNP ’s rotation , creating the westerlies . Because the westerlies form at the edge of each hemisphere ’s Hadley cell that is closest to the pole , the bigger the size of the cell , the more the winds move toward the pole . NNS collected by NN balloons , satellites and other means VBG back to 1960 show that NNP ’s tropical belt has widened in the past few decades by a few degrees of latitude , effectively expanding the size of the Hadley cells . This is partly due to JJ NN , as predicted by NN models . At the same NN , the westerlies have been pushed poleward . With less distance to cover as they circle a narrower part of the globe , the law of conservation of angular momentum dictates that the winds should increase in speed , much IN an NN skater rotates faster when she draws in her arms . And measurements during the past three decades show that the westerlies have , indeed , intensified . As researchers were making sense of these NNS to the westerlies , other NNS began VBG measurements of CO₂ levels in the atmosphere to determine whether the shifting , speedier westerlies are causing a drop in the amount of CO ₂ being absorbed by the Southern Ocean . They had reason to suppose that this MD happen . IN any gas , NN dioxide exerts a pressure that depends on the amount of the gas relative to other gases in a mixture . If this so - called partial pressure of NN dioxide ( pCO₂ ) of the atmosphere is greater than the pCO ₂ of the ocean , then the ocean will absorb NN from the atmosphere . Otherwise it will release it . And as the westerlies VBP stronger , the pCO ₂ of the Southern Ocean MD VB , due to shifts in the pattern of ocean currents . The westerlies drive the Southern Ocean current that circles Antarctica . The predominantly west - to - east current is further acted upon by a force generated by NNP ’s rotation , VBN as the Coriolis force , which deflects moving objects to their NN in the Northern Hemisphere and to their left in the Southern Hemisphere . The current circling Antarctica is deflected to its left , or northward , pushing the NN waters away from the pole . This sets the stage for NN from deep in the Southern Ocean to move to the NN . Up to 80 percent of all the deep NN that returns to the NN IN the globe makes that return in the Southern Ocean . “ It ’s unique , ” VBZ NN scientist Joellen Russell of the NNP of Arizona in Tucson . “ There 's nothing IN it in the NN . ” This massive upwelling of the deeper , NN - rich waters of the Southern Ocean increases the pCO ₂ of the ocean NN , which decreases its capacity to act as a NN sink , the argument goes . But is this what is actually happening ? The Southern Ocean has been loath to reveal its workings . This is due to the complicating effects of local wind patterns and the fact that researchers are only just beginning to make direct measurements of the outgassing of CO ₂ during peak winter months there . So far , the NNS paint a somewhat confusing , and concerning , picture . Previous estimates had shown that between 1981 and 2004 , the Southern Ocean absorbed about 80 CD fewer metric tons of NN per NN than expected . This was a NN for concern , given that the Southern Ocean is “ the most important marine NN sink on the NN , ” VBZ ocean biogeochemist Peter Landschützer of the Max Planck Institute for Meteorology in Hamburg , Germany . So Landschützer and his colleagues took a closer look at a JJ database of pCO ₂ values , created from observations of NN waters by instruments deployed in the NN or carried on research and commercial ships . VBN as the NNP Ocean CO₂ Atlas ( SOCAT ) and established in 2007 , it contains almost 26 CD observations of JJ oceans and coastal seas from 1957 to 2019 . Since NNS are sparser for the earlier decades than for recent NNS , Landschützer ’s team filled in the gaps VBG other , less direct but more frequently measured parameters such as NN NN NN and salinity and their well - understood relationship to pCO ₂ of NN waters . They estimated that the Southern Ocean had indeed taken in less CO₂ than expected from 1982 to 2001 . The trend reversed in 2002 , with the ocean acting as a more vigorous NN sink all the NN up to 2011 . From 2011 to CD , however , the Southern Ocean went back to being less effective in its NN absorption . The team tried to find a link between the NNS in the Southern Ocean ’s ability to absorb CO ₂ and the poleward - shifted westerlies . “ We were quite surprised that we did not , ” Landschützer VBZ . This called for an explanation , and the answer turned out to be complicated . Further analysis showed that the changing westerlies are , indeed , increasing the upwelling of NN - rich deep waters near Antarctica . This effect , though , is being offset further north in the Southern Ocean by an increased NN uptake in regions where the westerlies are blowing less vigorously than in the past . This MD imply that there should be no overall NN in the absorption of NN . But Landschützer ’s team VBD that the Southern Ocean ’s ability to absorb NN is increasing or decreasing over timescales of roughly a decade . The researchers put these flips down to the local wind patterns in JJ parts of the Southern Ocean VBN as the Atlantic , Pacific and Indian sectors . Winds there seem to VB every decade , as evidenced by about 35 NNS of NNS , and those local alterations line up well with NN absorption trends , Landschützer VBZ . All of the above analysis was VBN on NNS collected by ships plying the Southern Ocean mainly during summer . The NNS for the winter season was spotty ; it is hard for ships to venture close to Antarctica at that NN . So Landschützer ’s team VBD the richer summer NNS and the sparse winter NNS to extrapolate and account for the winter months as best they MD . But in recent NNS , researchers have started VBG floats that are offering a JJ , broader glimpse of winter goings - on in the Southern Ocean . And the NNS are disconcerting . Oceanographer Alison Gray of the NNP of NNP and her colleagues VBD NNS collected by 35 of these autonomous floats , deployed by the Southern Ocean NNP and NNP Observations and Modeling ( SOCCOM ) project . The floats , which had continuously monitored the top 2,000 meters of the Southern Ocean waters from NNP 1 , 2014 , to NNP 1 , 2017 , have sensors for a range of ocean NN parameters , and these can be VBN to calculate the pCO ₂ of the NN waters . The analysis by Gray ’s team showed that the Southern Ocean IN Antarctica is outgassing significantly more CO₂ in the winter than Lanschützer ’s methodology estimated . To VB if they MD resolve the discrepancy , Landschützer and colleagues combined the NN sets and VBD that “ the truth lies somewhere in the middle , ” he VBZ : The NN uptake is not as low as the direct float measurements suggest , but neither is it as high as estimated by the ship - only NN . While more work will VB NN NNS understand exactly what ’s happening in the Southern Ocean , for the NNP of Arizona ’s Russell , the direct winter NNS from the SOCCOM floats is already raising alarms . “ In the deep winter , when the winds are howling the strongest and the deepest layers are being stirred to the NN , that ’s when we 're tapping those older NN waters , ” she VBZ . “ And that 's what 's worrisome . ” The deep waters are NN - rich because of the microscopic marine algae called phytoplankton that live in the NN waters . The phytoplankton photosynthesize the CO₂ in the NN into organic molecules to build their bodies . When they die , they sink to the ocean floor , sequestering the NN for centuries . Some phytoplankton are consumed by larger organisms called zooplankton , which in turn are eaten by RB bigger creatures whose NN - rich fecal pellets and dead bodies can RB end up on the ocean floor , burying ever more NN in the deep waters . The NN from the SOCCOM floats suggests that it ’s these deep waters that are upwelling during the Antarctic winters . “ It 's the old rotted NN that normally takes hundreds of NNS to circulate out of the deep , ” Russell VBZ . NNS surmise that intensifying westerlies are bringing more of this NN - rich deep NN to the NN — but they VBP more NN . CD NN to confirm that speedier westerlies have an impact on Southern Ocean outgassing , and thus on the levels of atmospheric CO₂ , is to look at past NN NN . Krystyna Saunders and her colleagues decided to look for some of that NN on subantarctic Macquarie Island , which lies about 1,500 kilometers from Tasmania , midway between Australia and Antarctica . At latitude degrees 54S , it ’s RB in the main band of the westerlies . Getting to Macquarie Island is no JJ feat , RB on the Aurora Australis , a 311 - NN - JJ icebreaker . Despite its size , the ship can be tossed RB by massive swells , the kind Shackleton wrote about . “ You can be lying down in your bunk , rolling from side to side and head to NN as the ship swirls RB , ” Saunders VBZ . “ If you VBP seasick IN me , it ’s quite horrible . ” On Macquarie Island , Saunders and her colleagues capitalized on a fortuitous natural record that provides clues to how strongly the winds IN the island have blown in the past . That record lies at the bottom of Emerald Lake , a body of freshwater on the island ’s western edge . It ’s exposed to the westerlies and thus to salty ocean spray blown in by the winds : The greater the wind speeds , the higher the salinity of the lake . The salinity in turn affects which NNS of diatoms , types of algae , can thrive in the lake . When they die , diatoms sink to the bottom of the lake and are buried in sediments on the lakebed , creating a layered chronicle of the salinity of the lake — and by proxy the speed of the winds . Saunders ’ team extracted sediment cores from the lakebed , focusing on layers that had accumulated during the Holocene , the present epoch in NNP ’s history that began about 11,700 NNS ago at the end of the last NN age . Having inferred the speeds of westerlies over the course of the Holocene , they then looked at NNS from NN cores drilled in Antarctica to VB a direct measure of the amount of CO₂ in the atmosphere over that same NN period . They VBD a clear correlation . “ If you look at periods when the winds were above their average strengths , and periods when NN dioxide was above its average concentration , they overlap , ” Saunders VBZ . This has implications for our understanding of the effect the westerlies have on the Southern Ocean ’s capacity to absorb NN . Saunders ’ NN supports the idea that as the westerlies speed up , the Southern Ocean will outgas more CO₂ — as shown by Gray ’s report on wintertime NNS collected by the SOCCOM floats — and goes against the analysis of 35 NNS of ship - VBN NNS by Landschützer ’s team . Only more studies , along the lines of Landschützer ’s attempt to reconcile the various datasets , will VB resolve this debate . There ’s CD more factor that MD feed into the vicious cycle that NNS fear MD already be underway in the Southern Ocean . NNS in the extensive Atlantic Ocean circulation NN that includes the Gulf Stream MD RB be exacerbating the NN of the Southern Ocean , which in turn MD be adding to the poleward shift and intensification of the westerlies . This circulation NN , called the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation , or AMOC , brings warm , salty NN NN to the north , where it cools and sinks and then heads back to the Southern Hemisphere through deeper ocean layers . NNS have VBN NN that the AMOC has been slowing down , particularly in the last 150 NNS compared to the preceding 1,500 NNS . CD indication of this is that particles being deposited on the ocean floor have been getting smaller and smaller : Fast - flowing NN can whisk away smaller particles , allowing only the larger particles to settle , whereas slower NN allows smaller and smaller particles to drop to the floor . Some of the AMOC ’s slowdown can be attributed to CD of the consequences of JJ NN : an increasing supply of glacial meltwater into the North Atlantic . This fresh NN reduces the salinity , and hence the density , of the NN waters . The formation of dense , salty , cold NN is essential for it to sink down to the deep ocean in the North , from where it makes its return to the Southern Hemisphere . This process is being disrupted by NN NN . Since 2004 , a project called RAPID has deployed moorings across the breadth and depth of the Atlantic at latitude degrees 26N ( stretching from Florida to Morocco ) , to directly measure NNS in the velocity of the AMOC . The measurements show that the current is indeed slowing down . But because of inherent decade - to - decade variations in the NN NN , 15 NNS ’ worth of direct measurements is n’t enough to establish a trend . So Levke Caesar , then with the Potsdam Institute for NNP Impact Research in Germany , and her colleagues extended this record back in NN by VBG actual measurements of NN NN NNS from 1870 to CD , combined with a high - resolution NN model to reconstruct the strength of the AMOC over the past 150 NNS or so . Their work shows that the circulation NN ’s strength declined to a minimum IN 1990 , then grew until the early 2000s , and then started declining again . Other NNS have VBN similar results . As RB as NN gas NNS continue to rise , “ all NN models predict a slowdown of the AMOC , ” Caesar VBZ . Because the AMOC transports heat from the south to the north , a slowdown effectively cools the Northern Hemisphere and heats up the Southern Hemisphere . This NN RB intensifies the westerlies and shifts them toward the South Pole , leading to a greater vertical churning of the Southern Ocean , which MD contribute to JJ NN by weakening the ocean ’s ability to absorb CO₂ . Since the likely result is RB more glacial meltwater flowing into the North Atlantic , this MD further weaken the AMOC . It has all the makings of a NN that ’s slipping out of NN . A similar runaway process is thought to have ended the last NN age , raising CO₂ levels from about 180 to 240 parts per CD . This rise happened from about 17,500 NNS ago to 11,700 NNS ago , causing the deglaciation that made NNP more habitable . Atmospheric CO ₂ levels are now past a whopping 410 ppm due to JJ activity , and rising . In a mere 250 NNS , we have increased CO ₂ levels by more than the amount that melted an icy NN over thousands of NNS . The winds are howling again over the Southern Ocean and are dangerously close to awakening a beast that , until now , has been helping us by absorbing copious amounts of NN . But RB the Southern Ocean is unlikely to cooperate forever . Editor 's note : An earlier version of the map showing how the westerlies are made had incorrect placement of NNP ’s geography . text: NNP Explained is a collaboration between The Conversation , Stuff and the NNP Zealand NNP NNP Centre to answer your questions about NN NN . If you have a question you ’d VB an expert to answer , please send it to climate.change@stuff.co.nz The flight shaming movement has raised our awareness of air travel ’s contribution to NN NN . With all the discussion , you might be surprised to learn that air travel globally only accounts for about 3 % of the NN JJ activities are causing . Why all the fuss ? Before I explain , I should come clean . I am writing this on the train from Christchurch to Kaikoura , where I will give a talk about my recent book # NoFly : walking the talk on NN NN . I have some NN in this game . Read more : Flight shame : flying less plays a JJ but positive part in tackling NN NN Taking a train IN NNP Zealand is no mean feat . In the North Island , the train between Auckland and Wellington runs only every second day . If you VBP off at a stop along the NN , you have to wait another CD days to continue your journey . You can catch a bus , but you ’ll spend that bus journey fantasising about the possibility of an overnight train service . So why do it ? A good deal of JJ NN NNS come from industrial processes or electricity generation under the NN of governments and corporations , rather than individual citizens . For JJ of us , a decision not to fly might be the most significant reduction in NNS we can make as individuals . As Swedish NN activist Greta Thunberg has shown , refusing to fly RB sends a powerful signal to others , by showing that you are willing to VB your own behaviour . Politicians and corporate NNS departments will take note if we start acting together . Aviation affects the NN in a variety of ways . Because any NN dioxide you emit stays in the atmosphere for hundreds of NNS , it does n’t matter much whether you release it from the exhaust pipe of your car at NN level or from a jet engine several kilometres high . Per passenger , a flight from Auckland to Wellington will put a similar amount of NN dioxide into the air as driving solo in your car . Catching the train will cut your NN NNS seven - fold . When aircraft burn jet fuel , however , they RB emit short - lived gases IN nitrogen oxides , which can react with other gases in the air within a day of being released . When nitrogen oxides are released at altitude they can react with oxygen to put more ozone into the air , but can RB remove methane . Ozone and methane are both NN gases , so this chain of chemical reactions can lead to both heating and cooling effects . Unfortunately the net result when these processes are added together is to drive more NN . Depending on the atmospheric conditions , aircraft can RB create contrails : clouds of tiny NN crystals . The NN is not as clear cut on how contrails influence the NN , but some studies suggest they MD have an effect as significant as the NN dioxide released during a flight . There is RB considerable uncertainty as to whether aircraft exhaust might affect cloud formation itself - this MD be a further significant contribution to NN . Read more : NN explained : why do n't we have electric aircraft ? Offsetting , by planting trees or restoring natural wildlands , will take NN dioxide back out of the atmosphere . But we MD have to do this on a massive scale to feed our appetite for flight . NNS from international air travel are not included in the Paris Agreement , although the NNP Nations has been working on the NNP Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation ( CORSIA ) , which MD begin to deal with these . Initially , the scheme will be voluntary . Airlines flying routes between NNS that join the scheme will have to offset any NNS above 2020 levels from January 2021 . NNS from flying stand to triple by 2050 if demand for air travel continues to grow . RB if air travel became NN neutral through the use of biofuels or electric planes , the effects from contrails and interactions with clouds mean that flying MD never be NN neutral . With no easy fixes on the horizon , JJ NNS are thinking hard about their NN to fly . This is why I took a NN off air travel ( alongside my colleague Quentin Atkinson ) in 2018 . I have been back on planes in 2019 , but I have learned how to reduce my flying , by combining trips and making better use of NN conferencing . Fly if you must , offset if you can , but – if you are concerned about NN NN – CD of the best things you MD choose to do is to fly less .

text: NN NN presents clear and pressing threats to business — materials and product shortages , NN volatility , legal bans or consumer backlash , and damaged transportation infrastructure , to name just a few . But there are opportunities as well . Lowitt , a consultant in the sustainability field , has developed a series of detailed checklists that will VB smart managers reduce operational , regulatory , and reputational NN while finding JJ ways to cut costs , improve performance , enhance customer relationships , and otherwise increase competitiveness . The checklist recommendations , tested and refined through Lowitt ’s research into and work with firms including Coca - Cola , GE , and Owens Corning , cover four broad areas in the product NN cycle : sourcing , manufacturing , distribution , and consumption . Actions range from educating and incentivizing employees to use NN NN –conscious behavior to measuring and reporting key metrics to determining when alternative materials , methods , sites , or contract partners MD be called for . IN any such tool , the checklists do n’t provide a CD - size - fits - all plan . text: AN ENORMOUS NN sheet is at NN of melting RB if NNS rise by just 2 °C , potentially sparking major NN chaos . NNS VBP that if the East Antarctic NNP Sheet – which is 60 times the size of England – melts , NN levels MD rise by four metres , putting areas of the UK at NN of disappearing entirely . Experts are now warning that more needs to be done to prevent continued JJ NN . Melting NN can have a devastating effect on the NN , causing the NN to heat up more quickly , changing ocean circulation systems that regulate JJ NN , and increasing the NN of flooding and tsunamis damage . A NN into historical NN loss suggests RB " moderate NN " of NNP MD melt the East Antarctic NNP Sheet . " With current JJ NNS already CD degree higher than during pre-industrial times , future NN loss seems inevitable if we fail to reduce NN NNS , " VBD Dr David Wilson , of Imperial College London , who worked on the research . NNS have poured lots of effort into investigating the West Antarctic NNP Sheet , which mostly sits on land below NN level . Due to its low - lying position , it contributes to most of the continent 's NN melt today . But experts at Imperial College London and the NNP of Queensland have now investigated risks facing the East Antarctic NNP Sheet . The EAIS is the largest NN sheet on NNP , and poses a major hazard if it disappears . Now a NN in Nature suggests that 2 °C of NN over " a couple of millennia " MD VB significant melting of the EAIS . " Antarctica is RB twice the size of Australia , with NN sheets several kilometres thick and containing RB half of the NN 's fresh NN , " VBD Dr Kevin Welsh , at the NNP of Queensland , a co-author on the NN . " The East Antarctic NNP Sheet covers about CD thirds of the area , and because its base is largely above NN level it was generally thought to be less sensitive to NN climates than the adjacent West Antarctic NNP Sheet . " However , some areas – IN the Wilkes Land Subglacial Basin , directly south of Australia – are below NN level and contain enough NN to raise JJ NN levels by several metres . " The NN we have suggests that with the predicted 2 °C NN in Antarctica – if sustained over a couple of millennia – the sheet MD start melting in these locations . " Glaciers , which are created by NN sheets , grind up rocks on land . These rocks are then transported into the nearby Southern Ocean as sediment . This creates a record of earlier erosion by the NN sheet . Researchers chemically analysed layers of sediment from the ocean floor , which MD have originated from the Wilkes Subglacial Basin – collected as part of the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program . The NN looked at sediment layers that had settled on the seafloor during the four warm intervals occurring between NN ages over the last 450,000 NNS . " Studying NN sheet behaviour in the geological past can inform us about future NNS , " VBD Dr Wilson . " By building a picture of how the NN sheet has grown and shrunk as NNS have fluctuated , we can understand the response of the EAIS to future NN . " The team VBD chemical " fingerprints " in the sediment which revealed the patterns of erosion as the NN sheet advanced and retreated . It turned out that the NN sheet had retreated from its current size during some of these warmer " interglacial " periods , between 125,000 and 400,000 NNS ago . Importantly , at the NN , NNS were as little as CD degrees warmer than pre-industrial times – and CD degree warmer than today . During these warmer periods , JJ NN levels were between six and 13 metres higher than they are today . According to researchers , if all the NN in the Wilkes Subglacial Basin melted in modern times , JJ NN levels MD rise by up to four metres . " We VBD that the most extreme NNS in the NN sheet occurred during CD interglacial periods 125,000 and 400,000 NNS ago , when JJ NN levels were several metres higher than they are today , " Dr Walsh explained . " These periods MD be analogues for future climates and it seems likely that NN loss from the East Antarctic NNP Sheet contributed to those higher NN levels . Last month , NNS issued a warning about the NN of “ devastating tsunamis ” caused by NN NN . Research in NNP Advances suggested that rising NN levels – caused by JJ NN – significantly increase the threat of giant killer waves . Experts modelled the impact of tsunamis VBN on NN level increases , and discovered worrying results . It VBD that rising NN levels allowed tsunamis to reach much further inland , significantly increasing the NN of floods . This means JJ tsunamis that might not be deadly today MD wreak havoc in the future . “ Our research shows that NN - level rise can significantly increase the tsunami hazard , which means that smaller tsunamis in the future can have the same adverse impacts as JJ tsunamis MD today , ” VBD Robert Weiss , a professor of geosciences at Virginia Tech . And if you VBP Britain is safe from tsunamis , VB again . Earlier this week , research revealed that deadly tsunamis crashing into the UK is more common than previously thought . NNS VBP three killer waves have hit the UK within the last 10,000 NNS – raising the possibility that another NN MD be due . text: The aim of the current paper is to update the previous NN on NN NN fingerprints in European phenology and include as JJ plant NNS / phenophases as are available . Recent publications have exclusively focused on a few prominent spring leaf unfolding phases and results of those MD be strongly related to the choice of analysed NNS , having JJ sensitivities and covering JJ seasons . Phenology is controlled by seasonal patterns in the NN signal ( Lapenis FW al. , 2014 ) and these will vary by location ( spatial differences in the NN signal ) and NN period ( temporal differences in the NN signal , e.g. Rutishauser FW al. , 2009 ) . Consequently , this update is more than timely since the NN signal has not been stable , but temporal variations or trends in NN NN have been reported , especially related to the so called hiatus or standstill period ( Zang , Jochner ‐ Oette , Cortés , Rammig , & Menzel , 2019 ) . A publication has already indicated that there were no trends in spring and autumn phenology during this NN hiatus period ( Wang FW al. , 2019 ) . Another phenological regime shift in the mid‐1980s was RB related to discontinuous NN NNS ( Reid FW al. , CD ) . NN sensitivity has RB been shown to vary with specific plant traits , such as evolutionary relatedness , and to support invasions and plant performance ( e.g. Wolkovich , Cook , & Davies , 2014 ) . For wheat and maize in agriculture there are hints of geographic differences among cultivars in sensitivity to vernalization , day length and NN ( Van Bussel , Stehfest , Siebert , Müller , & Ewert , 2015 ) . However , there are still major NN gaps concerning the so‐called ‘ JJ ’ phenological phases , such as sowing or harvesting in agriculture , whose timings are decided by farmers . The GCB2006 NN and follow ‐up publications provided the JJ NN that the phenological signal in agriculture was weaker than the signal for wild growing plant NNS ( Bock , Sparks , Estrella , & Menzel , 2013 ; Estrella , Sparks , & Menzel , 2007 ; Menzel , Sparks , Estrella , Koch , FW al. , 2006 ; Menzel , Vopelius , Estrella , Schleip , & Dose , 2006 ) . However , it can be anticipated that , sooner or later , agricultural management and / or choice of cultivars will RB be adapted to the JJ potential growing seasons . The drivers of autumn phenology , such as leaf colouring and leaf fall , are still far from being completely understood ( Estrella & Menzel , 2006 ; Gallinat , Primack , & Wagner , CD ; Gill FW al. , 2015 ; Wu FW al. , 2018 ) . Major factors that MD impact on the results of this update are JJ NNS in ( apparent ) NN sensitivity ( e.g . Fu , Piao , FW al. , 2015 ; Fu , Zhao , FW al. , 2015 ) . NN ‐specific increases in heat requirements related to a decrease in chilling have been especially identified as the main reason ( Fu , Piao , FW al. , 2015 ) . However , there are RB contrasting opinions for example , by Wang FW al. ( 2017 ) . Güsewell , Furrer , Gehrig , and Pietragalla ( 2017 ) showed that for Switzerland there are still no indications of a lack of chilling leading to altered NN sensitivities . NNS in NN sensitivities are reported as not uniform over NN ( Chen FW al. , 2019 ) and , in particular , a weakened NN response was observed since 2000 ( Fu FW al. , 2014 ) . Spatial variations in NN sensitivity have been linked to mean annual NN and to seasonal NN range ( Lapenis , Henry , Vuille , & Mower , 2014 ; Menzel , Sparks , Estrella , & Roy , 2006 ; Wang FW al. , 2014 ) . Both major backup systems to prevent a premature spring development ( chilling , photoperiod ) MD finally lead to nonlinear responses of phenological onset dates to forcing NNS ( Jochner , Sparks , Laube , & Menzel , CD ) . Thus , the well ‐accepted role of phenology as a NN NN indicator is VBN on the formal attribution of shifted phenological onset dates to anthropogenic ‐induced NN ( Rosenzweig FW al. , 2007 , 2008 ) , demonstrating at the same NN that the phenological trends are not just natural variability , for example , as shown by Guan ( 2014 ) for CD phenophases which unequivocally corresponded to the respective winter / spring NN trends . Most studies , however , rely on proof of the sensitivity of phenological phases to NN as the fundamental prerequisite of NN NN detection and attribution , and have linked phenological NNS to NN increases ( e.g . Cook FW al. , 2012 ; Thackeray FW al. , CD ) . Since there is thorough NN that spring phenological development is RB partially triggered by fulfilment of winter chilling and by photoperiod ( e.g. Laube FW al. , 2014 ; Tang FW al. , CD ; Vitasse & Basler , 2013 ) , it is debated whether phenological NNS still mirror the recent ongoing NN , or mirror it to the same extent as before . Therefore , an update of the assessment of phenological NNS across Europe and their attribution to NN NN is necessary . In contrast to the GCB2006 publication , this update will uniquely concentrate on plant phenology . Although plant phenology is CD of the oldest forms of JJ monitoring , with phenological observations taken by ancient civilizations ( Koch FW al. , 2007 ; Schwartz , 2003 ) , it was only in the 1990s that its renaissance started with key publications on detection of NN NN impacts on JJ vegetation . Keeling , Chin , and Whorf ( 1996 ) were the JJ to report a 7 day earlier start of the growing season VBN on long‐term measurements of atmospheric CO 2 concentration , which Myneni , Keeling , Tucker , Asrar , and Nemani ( 1997 ) confirmed VBG normalized difference vegetation index satellite NNS from the Northern Hemisphere . Menzel and Fabian ( 1999 ) then provided the necessary ground truth by their analyses of long‐term European phenological NNS . JJ other papers , summarized in well ‐cited reviews and relevant chapters in IPCC reports ( e.g. Rosenzweig FW al. , 2007 ; Walther FW al. , 2002 ) , confirmed the extraordinary role of phenology as a bio‐indicator of NN NN . While research initially focused purely on the identification of NNS , it then extended to communication of NN NN to the general NN ( e.g. Van Vliet FW al. , 2003 ) as well as on various ecological consequences of these NNS ( Morisette FW al. , 2009 ; Thackeray FW al. , 2010 ) . Nevertheless , at the beginning of this renewed research there was a latent accusation of a publication bias , or cherry picking , in the sense that only the most advancing records or extraordinary NNS VBD their NN into popular scientific journals . Therefore , the COST725 initiative collected all available European phenological NNS ( later developed as the PEP725 database , Templ FW al. , 2018 ) and analysed more than 100,000 NN series for NN NN ‐driven NNS ( Menzel , Sparks , Estrella , Koch , FW al. , 2006 , hereafter referred as GCB2006 ) . The GCB2006 NN concluded that there was indeed a strong response in European phenology to NN NN and that these NNS matched the NN pattern . With more than 1,500 citations in the Web of NNP Core Collection , this NN has a high relevance for the scientific discourse on NN NN impacts on the biosphere . It was RB the backbone of the corresponding assessment of observed NNS and responses in natural and managed systems of AR4 WGII of the IPCC ( Rosenzweig FW al. , 2007 ) as well as of the subsequent paper of attribution of JJ impacts in nature to anthropogenic NN ( Rosenzweig FW al. , 2008 ) . Second , we applied a spatial approach VBN on all sites for which we tested the effect of the corresponding NN trends on all phenological trends . For this we divided all ( significant as well as non‐significant ) NN trends in terciles ( below , average , above ) on a seasonal basis and the phenological trends by sign and significance ( negative significant , negative nonsignificant , positive nonsignificant , positive significant ) . ( 2007 , 2008 ) . RB , VBN on statistically significant trends only , the percentage of significant trends ( out of all significant trends ) matching the direction expected from NN NN was determined , both for the phenological groups of GCB2006 and of Update . According to IPCC likelihood terminology , > 66 % probability corresponds to ‘ likely ’ , > 90 % to ‘ very likely ’ , and > 95 % to ‘ extremely likely ’ . In the results section , the model coefficients are visualized VBG so ‐called effect plots , which plot the predicted effect of each explanatory variable on the outcome . This makes comparisons easier with respect to the JJ units and range of the explanatory variables , and allows the identification of interaction terms and smooth terms . The effect of each variable is calculated by holding all other variables constant ( except for interactions ) . The models were fitted in R statistical software version 3.6 VBG the mgcv‐package ( Wood , 2017 ) , effects were calculated VBG the emmeans ‐package ( Lenth , 2019 ) , and results were visualized VBG the ggplot2 ‐ package ( Wickham , CD ) . In order to understand what the partial contribution of explanatory factors to the observed phenological trend was , we followed a modelling approach . Explanatory factors / variables were the nine clusters ( cluster9 , VB Table 2 ) , topography ( longitude , latitude and elevation ) , traits ( woodiness , pollination mode ) , start NN of records and number of recorded NNS . The E‐OBS v19.0HOM gridded NNS set with a 0.25 degree regular grid ( Cornes , Schrier , Besselaar , & Jones , 2018 ) , which is the homogenized version of E‐OBS v19.0e and thus more suitable to derive long‐term trends , was VBN for extracting the daily mean NN for all stations during 1951 – 2018 . Thus a GCB2006s ( s = simulated ) NNS set was defined as a subset of Update containing identical NNS / phases / stations , but restricted to the GCB2006 period and series length ( 1971 –2000 , 15 + NNS ) . The update of the GCB2006 NN almost CD decades later has clearly revealed that there is still a significant NN NN pattern in European plant phenology . Since a direct comparison of the almost 97,000 Update series to the GCB2006 ones was not possible , we simulated GCB2006s results VBN on Update to VB the effects of ongoing NN NN after 2000 as well as of longer series ( 15 + vs. 30 + NNS ) . Differences in the trend structure of GCB2006 and GCB2006s suggested that any results of trends analyses MD RB partly be driven by the set of NNS and phenophases included . In our NN a considerable adjustment in the observational programme of the DWD in 1991 has led to a substantial reduction in the number of ( agricultural ) NNS / phases when series were selected to end in 2000 or later . ZAMG NN selection mirrors a similar decrease of observations in the last CD decades ( VB Figure S1 b ) . In the following the results will be discussed with respect to the three guiding research questions . There is still a clear picture of phenological advance except for autumn . For the vegetative and generative phases of crops , fruit trees and wild plants , longer NN series ( 30 + NNS in Update ) led to ≥90 % advancing trends in spring ( Cg , FWv , FWg ) , ≥ 81 % for Cv and FWg , and ~ 75 % for the farmers ’ activities in these seasons ( F , F ) . Accordingly , at least 30 + NN series are needed for robust trend estimations ( Dose & Menzel , 2004 ; Rosenzweig FW al. , 2007 ) as RB confirmed by our trend modelling . Longer series were RB linked to a higher percentage of significant trends , but assuming comparable variability and NN rates , greater statistical NN MD be expected to lead to an increase in significance . Although the proportion of trends that was significant increased , mean advances of spring and summer phases decreased in the extended period beyond 2000 , especially for fruit trees and wild plants , but RB to a lesser degree for crops . This confirms findings of a review by Piao FW al. ( 2019 ) of decelerated or RB reversed trends in recent NNS . Only farmers ’ spring activities exhibited a stronger advance ( −0.116 ± 0.005 days / NN ) in Update which is well explained by considerably earlier dates in 2011 –2018 as shown in the anomaly plots . ( 2007 ) . The spatial approach confirmed this attribution , however , to a lesser degree . text: Were the predictions we made about NN NN 20 NNS ago accurate ? Here 's a look When it comes to NN NN , did we accurately predict in 2000 what MD be happening now ? text: Mass extinctions are very important to how NN evolved on NNP . For example , when an asteroid hit the NNP 66 CD NNS ago , the resulting dinosaur extinction led mammals to take their place . My colleagues and I have published JJ research on the mass extinction that took place 359 CD NNS ago at the boundary between the Devonian and Carboniferous geological periods . There have been JJ previous speculations as to the NN of this event , including volcanic eruptions , asteroid impacts , NN NN , NN level NNS , wildfires and the rise of the JJ forests . But we have shown that the extinctions on land at this NN MD have been caused by a catastrophic thinning of the ozone layer that let in damaging levels of ultra-violet radiation . Something similar contributed to the mass extinctions at the end of the Permian and Triassic periods , but these events were caused by volcanic eruptions . Our research suggests the NNP has a natural internal process triggered by a VBG NN that can destroy the ozone layer , a serious warning for our own period of NN NN . The Late Devonian extinction played a significant role in the development of vertebrate NN . It included the loss of the dominant group of armoured freshwater fish . The survivors were the sharks and the rather minor group of bony fish that subsequently spread out to dominate our younger oceans . The event RB shaped our own evolution because it led to the extinction of the JJ four - legged “ tetrapods ” . These were “ fish ” whose fins had evolved to become limbs with between six and eight fingers and toes . The JJ land - dwelling tetrapods with five fingers and toes – our ancestors – do n’t appear in the fossil record until after this extinction . To find out exactly what caused the Late Devonian extinction , we looked for NN of what happened in the atmosphere that was captured by fossilised plants from before and after the event . In particular , we looked at the resistant walls of the microscopic remains of pollen and spores , taken from fossils VBN in East Greenland and released by dissolving the rock samples in acid . The resistant walls of spores and pollen are there to protect the cell contents from ultra-violet radiation . But there is a brief interval between the creation of a JJ cell and the formation of its protective wall when it is vulnerable . The kinds of spores we examined are covered in JJ spines that are normally identical in length and have perfectly pointed tips . But most of the spines in our samples were malformed in a wild variety of shapes , suggesting the DNA of their cells was damaged by ultra-violet radiation . This suggests that the NNP ’s protective ozone shield was down as the spores were formed . Other spores and pollen had pigmented walls that acted as a protective tan , enabling those plants to survive . But a number of important plant groups quickly became extinct and the forest ecosystem collapsed . Those groups that survived were still disrupted and it took several CD NNS to rebuild , creating quite a JJ ecosystem in the process . Our samples came from a very JJ ancient lake that existed all NN round despite being in a very arid part of the NN . Such lakes only form when glaciers collapse and the NN ’s seasonal monsoon is very active due to solar heat , so the JJ NN must have been in a NN period . Other NNS have shown that high summer NNS over continental areas can increase the transport of NN vapour high into the atmosphere . This NN vapour carries with it organic NN compounds that include chlorine , which are produced naturally by a wide variety of plants , algae and fungi . Once these compounds are near the ozone layer , they release the chlorine and this breaks down ozone molecules . This produces a positive feedback loop because a collapsing terrestrial ecosystem will release a flush of nutrients into the oceans , which can VB a rapid increase in algae . So the more the ozone layer is damaged , the more plants die , and the more ozone - damaging compounds are released . Later on , the ozone layer will naturally recover as the NN cools and the algae helps remove NN dioxide from the atmosphere . The discovery of this potential JJ extinction mechanism indicates that a NN NN , such as we have now , has the potential to erode the ozone layer to let in damaging ultra-violet radiation . This has consequences for all NN on NNP , both on the land and in shallow waters . We VBP it is as important as recognising that asteroid impacts caused mass extinctions . Once we knew about the consequences of asteroid impacts , there followed an intense collective research effort to assess the threat . We now plot the paths of all JJ extra-terrestrial objects likely to come close to the NNP ’s orbit . Similarly , we now VBP to focus effort on understanding the links between JJ NN and the production and atmospheric transport of chlorine - bearing NN compounds that have the potential to VB similar destruction of our ozone layer . We now VBP to make further studies of the rocks with malformed spores to work out the duration of the extinction and the likely rate of NN NN required to push enough ozone - destroying chemicals high into the atmosphere . text: JJ NN NN has been measured since 1880 at a network of ground - VBN and ocean - VBN sites . Over the last century , the average NN NN of the NNP has increased by about 1.0o F . The eleven warmest NNS this century have all occurred since 1980 , with 1995 the warmest on record . The higher latitudes have warmed more than the equatorial regions . Beginning in 1979 , satellites have been VBN to measure the NN of the atmosphere up to a height of 30,000 NNS . The JJ - term NN record and the recent satellite observations differ , but that fact is not surprising : the CD techniques measure the NN of JJ parts of the NNP NN ( the NN , and various layers of the atmosphere ) . In addition to this , a variety of factors , such as the presence of airborne materials from the 1991 eruption of the volcano Mt. Pinatubo , affect each record in a JJ NN . Satellite observations were initially interpreted as showing a slight cooling , but more recent analyses accounting for natural , short - term fluctuations imply NN , just as the ground - VBN measurements have indicated over a longer NN period . Increased amounts of NN in the atmosphere will mean more rain or snow overall . We MD be seeing the JJ signs of NNS in the NN cycle . Between 1981 and 1991 , the length of the growing season in the northern high latitudes ( between 45 oand 70o N ) increased by a total of up to twelve days , as documented by satellite imagery . The melting of glaciers , which has occurred worldwide over the last century , RB contributes to the rise . Formerly frozen soils ( permafrost ) in the Alaskan and Siberian arctic have RB begun to melt , damaging both ecosystems and infrastructure . An ‘ informal ’ explanation of a Lunar Standstill event we can read from the Wikipedia archives , and which VBZ : " At the major lunar standstill , which takes place every 18.6 NNS , the range of the declination of the NNP reaches a maximum . As a result , at high latitudes , the NNP appears to move in just CD weeks from high in the sky to low on the horizon . This NN appears to have had special significance for the Bronze Age societies who built the megalithic monuments in Britain , and it RB has significance for some neo -pagan religions . The next major lunar standstill occurs in 2006 . As the NNP spins on its axis , the stars above us appear to move in circles . It appears to us as if all the stars are fixed in a great sphere surrounding us . In the same NN that we measure positions on the NN VBG latitude and longitude , we measure positions of stars on this sphere in JJ Ascension ( equivalent to longitude ) and Declination ( equivalent to latitude ) . If you stand at a place on the NN which has latitude 50° , then the stars directly above you have a declination of 50° . Unlike the stars , the NNP and NNP do not have a fixed declination . As the NNP travels its annual orbit IN the NNP , with its rotational axis tilted at about 23.5° from the axis of orbital motion ( a straight line joining a point on the tropic of cancer the ' opposite ' point on the tropic of capricorn ) , the NNP 's declination NNS from +23.5° in June to - 23.5° in December . Thus , in the Northern hemisphere , the NNP is higher in the sky in June , causing summer , than it is in December , when the NNP is low in the sky and is only above the horizon for a short NN , causing winter . The NNP RB VBZ in declination , but it does so in only a month , instead of a NN for the NNP . So it might VB from a declination of +25° to - 25° in just CD weeks , returning to + 25 ° CD weeks later . Thus , in just CD month the NN can move from being high in the sky , to low on the horizon , and back again . But , unlike the NNP , the maximum and minimum declination reached by the NNP RB varies . This is because the orbit of the NNP 's revolution about the NNP is inclined by about 5° to the orbit of the NNP 's revolution IN the NNP , and so the maximum declination of the NN varies from ( 23.5° - 5° ) =18.5° to ( 23.5°+5° ) =28.5° . The effect of this is that at CD particular NN ( the minor lunar standstill ) , the NNP will VB its declination during the month from +18.5° to - 18.5° , which is a total movement of 37° . This is not a particularly JJ NN , and MD not be very noticeable in the sky . However , 9.3 NNS later , during the major lunar standstill , the NNP will VB its declination during the month from +28.5° to - 28.5° , which is a total movement of 57° , and which is enough to take it from high in the sky to low on the horizon in just CD weeks . text: A hydrocarbon is an organic chemical compound composed exclusively of hydrogen and NN atoms . Hydrocarbons are naturally - occurring compounds and form the basis of crude oil , natural gas , coal , and other important NN sources . Hydrocarbons are highly combustible and produce NN dioxide , NN , and heat when they are burned . Therefore , hydrocarbons are highly effective as a source of fuel . Hydrocarbons occur naturally throughout the NN , originating from plant and animal fossils that have been formed by the forces of NN and weight over millennia . They are mostly VBN deep underground , in porous rock formations ( such as sandstone , limestone , and shale ) . Porous rock formations are often VBN in JJ bodies of NN , so there is an immense quantity of hydrocarbons trapped deep beneath the oceans . Oil and natural gas exploration NNS use advanced engineering techniques to identify these potential reservoirs and pull their resources to the NN for JJ use . Examples of such technologies include offshore oil platforms , directional drilling , and enhanced oil recovery ( EOR ) techniques . Hydrocarbons are very important for the modern economy . Globally , hydrocarbons are responsible for roughly 85 % of NN consumption . This figure MD actually understate the role of hydrocarbons in the economy by a significant margin because they are VBN in a wide range of applications aside from their use as a source of NN . For example , refined petroleum has been VBN to produce myriad derivative materials that play critical roles in the JJ economy , such as plastics , solvents , and lubricants . JJ techniques are VBN to extract hydrocarbons , depending on the type and location of the reserve . For example , hydraulic fracturing — better VBN as “ fracking ” — is VBN to extract natural gas from shale rock by VBG pressurized fracking fluid to create fissures through which the gas can escape to the NN . Mining is VBN to access oil sands , which are unconventional deposits of crude oil that are heavily intermixed with sand and sandstone . Unfortunately , it is now understood that there is a serious JJ cost to VBG hydrocarbons as a primary source of NN . NN gasses released during the combustion of hydrocarbons are contributing to NN NN . The process of oil and gas extraction can damage the NN environment and surrounding groundwater of the extraction site . JJ economists argue that hydrocarbon NN production involves substantial negative externalities that are not sufficiently represented in the NN NN of oil and gas . In fact , considering the mounting cost of NN - NN - related phenomena , JJ argue that these externalities significantly outweigh any cost savings associated with hydrocarbons . To address these concerns , there is a growing movement toward the use of renewable NN sources , such as solar , nuclear , wind , and geothermal NN . Alongside innovations in battery technology and “ smart grid ” infrastructure , these JJ NN alternatives MD play a significantly larger role in JJ NN production in the NNS and decades ahead .

text: A noticeable increase in mean NN has already been observed in Switzerland and summer NNS up to 4.8 K warmer are expected by 2090 . This article reviews the observed impacts of NN NN on biodiversity and considers some perspectives for the future at the national level . The following impacts are already evident for all considered taxonomic groups : elevation shifts of distribution towards mountain summits , spread of thermophilous NNS , colonisation by JJ NNS from warmer areas and phenological shifts . Additionally , in the driest areas , increasing droughts are affecting tree survival and fish NNS are suffering from warm NNS in lowland regions . These observations are coherent with model projections , and future NNS will probably follow the current trends . These NNS will likely VB extinctions for alpine NNS ( competition , loss of habitat ) and lowland NNS ( NN or drought stress ) . In the very urbanised Swiss landscape , the high fragmentation of the natural ecosystems will hinder the dispersal of JJ NNS towards mountains . Moreover , disruptions in NN interactions caused by individual migration rates or phenological shifts are likely to have consequences for biodiversity . Conversely , the inertia of the ecosystems ( NN longevity , restricted dispersal ) and the local persistence of populations will probably result in lower extinction rates than expected with some models , at least in 21st century . It is thus very difficult to estimate the impact of NN NN in terms of NN extinctions . A greater recognition by society of the intrinsic value of biodiversity and of its importance for our existence will be essential to put in place effective mitigation measures and to safeguard a maximum number of native NNS .

text: — Our thanks to Kara Rogers and the Britannica Blog , where this post RB appeared on Oct. 12 , 2011 . Chirping from the talus slopes of the Teton Range in the Rocky Mountains , the JJ pika ( ) sends a warning call to intruders — in this NN NNS climbing up the switchbacks in Grand Teton National Park ’s Cascade Canyon . Sounding its alarm from a rocky perch , then darting into crevices and shadow on the steep slope , the rodent - sized , round - eared , brownish gray pika goes largely unnoticed . But as the second NNS petitioned for protection under the U.S. Endangered NNP Act ( ESA ) because of NN NN - associated threats ( the polar bear was the JJ ) , the pika cannot afford to be overlooked for much longer . The JJ pika lives primarily at elevations between 8,000 and 13,000 NNS , though it MD be VBN at significantly lower elevations , including a little above NN level . Low - elevation pika populations , however , are at high NN of NN NN , particularly local NN and decreased precipitation . Populations of pika in Yosemite National Park , for example , have migrated more than 500 NNS upslope over the course of the last century , a shift coincident with a NN increase of 5.4 °F in Yosemite during that same period of NN . More significantly , over the course of only a decade — between 1999 and 2008 — pikas in the Great Basin on the eastern edge of the Sierra Nevada experienced a nearly five - fold increase in extinction rate and an 11 - fold increase in the rate of upslope retreat . Pikas there are now moving upslope at a rate of 475 NNS per decade . In 2010 , despite the documented loss of pikas and NN linking pika declines and range shifts with NN NN , the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service ( FWS ) decided not to protect the JJ pika under the ESA . The decision was denounced by the nonprofit Centers for Biological Diversity , which had petitioned for the NN ’ protection , and was supported by some biologists , who claimed that most populations of the JJ pika are stable . Pikas , however , are highly susceptible to warm NNS and will die within several hours of constant exposure to NNS of 75 to 78 °F . Their survival RB appears to depend heavily on contiguous habitat . For instance , a NN of historical pika population sites in the southern Rockies , where pika habitat extends over a JJ area , revealed that just four out of 69 populations had been extirpated since the 1980s . The extirpations occurred at sites that were once wet but that had dried out over the course of the last 100 NNS . Contiguous habitat and upslope migration are the pika ’s only hope for escape from local NN NN and drying . But at higher elevations , food MD be scarce and the NN too cold , and given the isolation of pika populations , it remains to be seen whether migration and dispersal to JJ areas can actually rescue the NN . Furthermore , several decades into the future , the high , mountainous elevations where pikas can now find refuge MD no longer be cool and wet enough to support their survival . Indeed , NN prediction models have suggested that summertime NNS in pika habitat will increase by 5.4 °F by 2050 . While the FWS cited this figure in its report explaining why pika do not warrant protection under the ESA , such an increase will render the lower elevations of JJ mountain ranges , including the Teton Range , uninhabitable for pika . And while it is difficult to predict precise NN increases beyond 2050 , NNS likely will continue to rise , forcing the JJ pika higher and higher , further restricting its range and its chances of survival in the process .

text: ( Reuters ) - Unilever Plc ( ULVR.L ) VBD on Monday it will invest 1 CD euros in a fund to invest in NN NN projects and reduce to net zero NN gas NNS from all its NNS by 2039 , 11 NNS ahead of the Paris Agreement deadline . The net zero emission target is an extension of efforts already underway to cut NNS within the NN by 2030 - such as reducing electricity consumption within offices . Unilever , which has an annual turnover of 52 CD euros ( $ 58.5 CD ) , VBD it MD prioritise partnerships with suppliers who have set emission reduction targets and has set up a NN where suppliers must declare the NN footprint of goods and services provided . text: Lauren E. Oakes is a Conservation Scientist with the Wildlife Conservation Society , an Adjunct Professor at Stanford NNP in the Department of NNP NNP NNP , and the author of " In Search of the Canary Tree . " Sarah H. Olson is the Associate Director of epidemiology for the Wildlife Conservation Society NNP Program . James Watson is the Director of the NNP and Research Initiative at the Wildlife Conservation Society and a professor of conservation NN at the NNP of Queensland . The opinions expressed in this commentary are their own . View more opinion at CNN . ( CNN ) The NNP and its inhabitants face three JJ crises : the NN NN , the NN NN and biodiversity NN . Unto themselves , each already feels overwhelming -- in terms of JJ - NN consequences , the speed and scale of impacts , and the transformative actions needed to keep the NN habitable . CD commonality lies at the core of these massive JJ challenges : the destructive relationship between humanity and the natural NN . JJ activities drive these invisible enemies , and our hope for the future will derive from solutions VBN on caring for nature . With NNP - CD - related mortality expected to be high in vulnerable populations , at least CD expert , NYU NN economist Gernot Wagner , has likened the NN to " NN NN at warp speed . " The exponential growth rate of NNP - CD makes the NN far more apparent to most NNS , on a daily basis , than a NN NN .
