text: There is a strange contradiction at the heart of our federal NN and its response to NN NN . While most of NNP has been woefully neglectful of the NN or outright denying its existence , what is arguably our most conservative institution — the U.S. NN — has begun taking the NN very seriously . GOP legislators might make nonsensical statements about how “ NN level rise ” is a “ left - wing term , ” but the Pentagon is well aware of the dangers that NN NN — which it refers to as a ‘ threat multiplier ’ — poses for its installations and mission . After all , you “ ca n’t fight a NN unless you ’ve got a place to leave from , ” noted General Gerald Galloway , formerly of the Army Corps of Engineers . As JJ as 46 U.S. JJ bases were recently deemed threatened by the heightened NN of flood , drought , and wildfire brought on by NN NN . Diving into the armed forces ’ response to the NN NN , Michael T. Klare “ VBD they had some very interesting things to VB about it . ” Klare , 76 , recently retired from Hampshire College , where he was the Five College Professor Emeritus of Peace and NNP Security Studies . ( “ Well , now I work RB harder , ” he laughs . ) The author of 15 previous books and the defense correspondent for The Nation , Klare spoke with Rolling Stone about his forthcoming release , All Hell Breaking Loose : The Pentagon ’s Perspective on NNP NNP , which is due out this November from book publisher Metropolitan . The book synthesizes the latest NN papers , statements and presentations by officials , along with personal interviews , to give the most up - to - date perspective on NN as viewed through the lens of those tasked with defending NNP from threats of all types . Klare ’s project began because he was “ studying the intersections of NN NN , resource scarcity , and conflict ” and realized that the NN ’s take on JJ NN was a “ vision of NN NN that is not a part of the JJ discussion . ” While environmentalists point out the ecological issues involved , IN habitat destruction and mass extinctions , “ the NN focuses on the threat to JJ institutions and communities , ” he VBZ . The armed forces “ VBP the greatest threats from NN NN being NN collapse and mass migrations that are VBG to create chaos IN the NN ” and lead to a lot of dangerous tasks that “ they MD prefer not to have to undertake . ” The NN began making some reforms to address NN NN under the Obama administration , utilizing cleaner technologies through the Army ’s Operation Dynamo , the Marines ’ Experimental Forward Operating Base , and the Navy ’s Great Green Fleet . Obama had put through an executive order in 2013 requiring all parts of the federal NN to prepare for NN NN , but NNP rescinded it in 2017 . The various JJ branches continue to build toward ‘ net zero ‘ installations and the ability of each base to be self - reliant . “ At some point , [ JJ ] officers who view national security as a sacred obligation will have no choice but to confront those who persist in NN denial , ” writes Klare . The NN MD VB NN NN is a hoax created by the Chinese , but Klare ’s latest book shows that the Pentagon plans to stay the course in attempting to green its facilities , juggle multiple catastrophes at a NN , and prepare for the possibility of , well , all hell breaking loose . The idea of ‘ All Hell Breaking Loose , ’ in the title of your book , what does that mean for the NN ? They VBP their job as defending this country from foreign threats and that is what they are trained to do . ‘ All Hell Breaking Loose ’ is a condition they fear in which they will be unable to conduct that mission , to do their job , because they will be so caught up in protecting this country against NN NN threats or addressing its impacts on other NNS IN the NN that are collapsing because of the effects . I take this concept from the Cold NNP era of nuclear escalation that VBZ we VBP from JJ - scale events to increasingly serious ones . The NN sees that with NN NN as well . They VB an increase in extreme storm events that affect their allied NNS and require a JJ response providing aid — and in the U.S. itself , UH in Florida or Puerto Rico . But they look into the future and VBP increasingly severe events IN extreme droughts bringing about the collapse of entire nations . They VBP that happening potentially in places IN Nigeria and Pakistan , leading to mass chaos spreading across continents . They VBP that beginning in what we once called the Third NNP but spreading to more privileged and wealthier parts of the NN IN Europe , and bringing about upheaval there , leading eventually to conflict among the great powers as NN NN advances . Perhaps in the Can you quickly walk us through the ‘ Ladder of Escalation ’ model that you use for this book ? You write that the Pentagon began planning for what disaster experts call “ complex emergencies ” after the East Coast was walloped by Hurricane Sandy , and that it was the triple - assault of Hurricanes Irma , Maria , and Harvey — combined with massive wildfires in the west — that “ made the nightmare palpable ” for officials . What is a complex emergency , and what do they mean to the Pentagon ? The U.S. NNP has always played a role in the aftermath of emergencies , providing food , NN , supplies , helping rescue NNS and more . That ’s nothing JJ . But they find that as NN NN advances and increases in intensity , these emergencies will become more complex . The electrical grid will collapse . There will be chemical spills that produce all kinds of NN effects . The NN NN itself will collapse . The NN services will collapse . And so the NN will have to play a much greater role than they ever have before , stepping in and playing the various roles of governments and having to deal with lawlessness IN looting . In Puerto Rico , after Hurricane Maria , the systems of NN basically crashed in JJ places . There was no electricity or communications available and the NN came in and had to provide all of those services . There is a fear that in the future these kinds of emergencies , complex emergencies , will increase in severity and in number — and MD occur simultaneously — requiring a vast commitment of JJ forces at a NN when maybe those forces are needed elsewhere . The book talks about how NN systems will come under pressure because of NN NN , which MD give NN to conflict . Any areas we should be particularly leery about ? Places IN the NNS of northern Africa are already suffering terribly and we VBP that currently with localized conflicts . But as NN NN advances , RB bigger and more wealthy and powerful NNS will feel the effects . I VBP NN is the area where this will play itself out — NN shortages — and where CD or more NNS share the same source of NN : the Nile River , the Indus River and so on . CD that has caught my attention is the Brahmaputra River . It originates in the Himalayas and travels hundreds of NNS through NNP and Tibet and then crosses into northern India , where it continues for hundreds more NNS and then finally crosses into Bangladesh , joins with the Ganges River and empties out into the Indian Ocean . This is CD of the biggest and most important rivers in the NN for agriculture — hundreds of millions of NNS depend on it for growing their food . This river is threatened by NN NN because it derives from the Himalayian glaciers , which are VBG to disappear , and the river will likely diminish in flow . Meanwhile , NNP is threatening to dam the river upstream and divert its waters to parts of the country that are already suffering from NN scarcity . And India VBZ that that MD be a NN for NN because that river is so essential to the survival of their country that they wo n’t let it happen . So that is a scenario that worries me deeply . What are the ties between the globalization of the economy , a JJ JJ NN , and these complex emergencies ? How do those intersections potentially affect things IN pandemics ? RB of all , NN NN is making pandemics more likely because it improves the conditions for mosquitoes since they VBP hot , moist NN and that is what JJ NN is providing them with in JJ parts of the NN — including the southeastern NNP NNPS . We ’re VBG to VB more frequent pandemics in the future . Globalization helps that process due to the ease of airplane travel and whatnot — it can facilitate the spread of infectious diseases . I VBP this will create fears IN the NN , which will lead to quarantines , panics , and the militarization of NN [ services ] . We ’ve seen that at various stages in the past few NNS , IN borders being sealed off . That attitude will lead to a more militarized response to NN NN : fences , walls , and more . I do n’t VB you can solve NN NN or NN emergencies in this fashion , but I feel there will be a tendency to respond that NN . What about other aspects of globalization ? Should the migrant caravans be viewed as NN refugees , and how should the U.S. respond ? This is a major JJ issue in the NNP NNPS : How to address these massive migrations of desperate poor NNS from Central NNP who are fleeing violence and poverty and seeking refuge in the NNP NNPS . The claim is that those NNS are JJ refugees and should find refuge in an intermediate country , VB Guatemala or Mexico . But it is pretty evident that NN NN is a driving factor in their migration because of pronounced drought in much of the area . It ’s becoming impossible to grow crops there and these are agricultural regions . So , yes , these NNS are fleeing NN NN . I VBP as NN goes on this type of thing can only become a more powerful factor in NNS ’s decision to move . And there is VBG to be hostility to this process everywhere . JJ activists point out that the NN has garrisoned the NN with bases and is the largest consumer of oil as a result . Is the NN at all self - aware here ? Of course the NN is a JJ consumer of oil , and that contributes to NN NN . But this is something that NNS in the NN are very aware of . They were drawn to this topic originally not by NN NN but by the strategic implications of being all over the NN and depending on a JJ logistical trail of getting that petroleum there . And that logistical trail is very vulnerable to attack . In Afghanistan and Iraq , U.S. oil convoys were attacked all the NN . They still are . In JJ circumstances , more soldiers died defending convoys than died in battle . The NN is very determined to reduce their dependence on fuel that MD be subject to interference . It is RB at NN from NN NN because these JJ supply lines are increasingly VBG to be struck by severe NN events just IN everything else will be . So RB before they had any kind of green consciousness , JJ leaders were determined to try to reduce the oil consumption of their forces . Now they are RB concerned about NN NN ’s impacts on the JJ security environment , so they are RB trying to reduce their own contribution to JJ NN . And they ’re making some headway . Can they do more ? Yes . They can do a lot more . But I VBP that they are showing that they ’re capable of making progress in this direction . JJ NNS speak about a NNP NNP II - style mobilization to stop NN NN through a Green NNP Deal and the JJ . But what does it VB about our culture that NNS constantly VBP in these militarized analogies ? I VBP JJ NNS have difficulty with that notion , and I ’m RB ambivalent about whether a JJ metaphor is the JJ NN . NNS sometimes do speak about the Apollo Project [ the ambitious mission to VB to the NN ] , which I find a more comfortable notion of what we have to do . The U.S. NNP , when they speak about what they have to accomplish , does not speak in those terms . They VBP that ‘ we have a job to do , which is to defend this country against foreign threats ’ — very real JJ threats — ‘ and that ’s what we VBP to do . ’ But NN NN counts as an impediment to their real job and they have to address this and overcome it . And that means making its own bases resilient to NN NN and reducing their contribution to it . But they recognize it as a JJ problem and realize they cannot do it alone and have to cooperate with the militaries of other NNS in making their own NNS resilient . So they VBP this as an area of JJ - to - JJ cooperation . I VBP it in a more positive light in that sense . The now - retired Navy Admiral David Titley has mentioned a fear of ‘ ungoverned spaces ’ — why are such NN vacuums abroad so important to the NN and to the domestic security apparatus here at home ? The NN talks about ‘ ungoverned spaces ’ as places where NN NN has vanished . You can VB about a place IN Somalia where you once had a functioning NN that extended throughout the country but has RB - since disappeared . You have something that calls itself a ‘ NN . ’ Its reach does n’t extend much beyond the city limits of Mogadishu . The rest of the country is pretty much ungoverned and you have lots of contending forces — various terrorist groups IN NNP - Shabab , militias and more . These are areas where groups VBP that can flourish and hatch plots against the NNP NNPS . Will this occur here ? Certainly senior JJ officials in the U.S. fear that in the event of mass JJ catastrophes in the future , local governments will break down and there will be lawlessness in this country and the NN will be forced to step in . They saw elements of that with Hurricane Katrina in 2005 in NNP Orleans where the NN force basically disintegrated and vanished . The NN VBZ that with NN NN , the number of these ungoverned spaces is VBG to multiply because NNS in Africa and elsewhere will not be able to cope with the intense droughts that can lead to mass suffering and starvation , combined with severe NN events , food scarcity , NN scarcity and so on . They ’re just VBG to collapse under the weight of these pressures , which opens vast areas of the country to militia rule and terrorist infiltration . We VBP this in Libya , Mali , parts of Nigeria , and , of course , in Afghanistan . This is the future in a NN of NN NN .

text: • The NN is unlikely to hit the targets necessary to avoid catastrophic levels of NN NN . • Some VBP that as a last resort , we MD VB to temporarily cool the NN by modifying the skies . It ’s 2055 . A row of airplanes streak across the sky . They ’re barely visible because they ’re flying far above the usual traffic of jetliners , transport balloons , and delivery drones . The cloud creates a barrier that reflects sunlight back into NN , keeping it from being absorbed on NNP , where it MD further warm the NN . The planes do this every day , as they have for NNS . text: NNP Explained is a collaboration between The Conversation , Stuff and the NNP Zealand NNP NNP Centre to answer your questions about NN NN . If you have a question you ’d VB an expert to answer , please send it to climate.change@stuff.co.nz As someone who has been working on NN NN detection and its causes for over 20 NNS I was both surprised and not surprised that I was asked to write on this topic by The Conversation . For nearly all NN NNS , the NN is proven that NNS are the overwhelming NN of the JJ - term NNS in the NN that we are observing . And that this NN should be closed . Despite this , NN denialists continue to receive prominence in some NN which can lead NNS into thinking that man-made NN NN is still in question . So it ’s worth VBG back over the NN to remind ourselves just how much has already been established . Successive reports by the Intergovernmental Panel on NNP NNP – mandated by the NNP Nations to assess scientific NN on NN NN – have evaluated the causes of NN NN . The most recent special report on JJ NN of 1.5 degrees confirms that the observed NNS in JJ and regional NN over the last 50 or so NNS are almost entirely due to JJ influence on the NN NN and not due to natural causes . RB we should perhaps ask what we mean by NN NN . The Intergovernmental Panel on NNP NNP defines NN NN as : The causes of NN NN can be any combination of : • None Internal variability in the NN NN , when various components of the NN NN – IN the atmosphere and ocean – vary on their own to VB fluctuations in climatic conditions , such as NN or rainfall . These internally - driven NNS generally happen over decades or longer ; shorter variations such as those related to El Niño fall in the bracket of NN variability , not NN NN . • None Natural external causes such as increases or decreases in volcanic activity or solar radiation . For example , every 11 NNS or so , the NNP ’s magnetic field completely flips and this can VB JJ fluctuations in JJ NN , up to about 0.2 degrees . On longer NN scales – tens to hundreds of millions of NNS – geological processes can drive NNS in the NN , due to shifting continents and mountain building . • None JJ influence through NN gases ( gases that trap heat in the atmosphere such as NN dioxide and methane ) , other particles released into the air ( which absorb or reflect sunlight such as soot and aerosols ) and land - use NN ( which affects how much sunlight is absorbed on land surfaces and RB how much NN dioxide and methane is absorbed and released by vegetation and soils ) . What NNS have been detected ? The Intergovernmental Panel on NNP NNP ’s recent report showed that , on average , the JJ NN air NN has risen by 1 °C since the beginning of significant industrialisation ( which roughly started in the 1850s ) . And it is increasing at ever faster rates , currently 0.2 °C per decade , because the concentrations of NN gases in the atmosphere have themselves been increasing ever faster . The oceans are VBG as well . In fact , about 90 % of the extra heat trapped in the atmosphere by NN gases is being absorbed by the oceans . A warmer atmosphere and oceans are causing dramatic NNS , including steep decreases in Arctic summer NN NN which is profoundly impacting arctic marine ecosystems , increasing NN level rise which is inundating low lying coastal areas such as Pacific island atolls , and an increasing frequency of JJ NN extremes such as drought and heavy rain , as well as disasters where NN is an important driver , such as wildfire , flooding and landslides . Multiple lines of NN , VBG JJ methods , show that JJ influence is the only plausible explanation for the patterns and magnitude of NNS that have been detected . This JJ influence is largely due to our activities that release NN gases , such as NN dioxide and methane , as well sunlight absorbing soot . The main sources of these NN gases and particles are fossil fuel burning , cement production , land cover NN ( especially deforestation ) and agriculture . Most of us will struggle to pick up slow NNS in the NN . We feel NN NN largely through how it affects NN from day - to - day , season - to - season and NN - to - NN . The NN we experience arises from dynamic processes in the atmosphere , and interactions between the atmosphere , the oceans and the land NN . JJ influence on the broader NN NN acts on these processes so that the NN today is JJ in JJ ways from how it MD have been . CD NN we can more clearly VB NN NN is by looking at severe NN events . A branch of NN NN , called extreme event or NN attribution , looks at memorable NN events and estimates the extent of JJ influence on the severity of these events . It uses NN models run with and without measured NN gases to estimate how individual NN events MD have been JJ in a NN without NN NN . As of early 2019 , nearly 70 % of NN events that have been assessed in this NN were shown to have had their likelihood and / or magnitude increased by JJ influence on NN . In a NN without JJ NN , these events MD have been less severe . Some CD % of the studies showed a reduction in likelihood , while for the remaining 20 % JJ NN has not had a discernible effect . For example , CD NN showed that JJ influence on NN had increased the likelihood of the 2015 - 2018 drought that afflicted Cape Town in South Africa by a factor of three . NN extremes underlie JJ of the hazards that damage society and the natural environment we depend upon . As JJ NN has progressed , so have the frequency and intensity of these hazards , and the damage they VBP . Minimising the impacts of these hazards , and having mechanisms in place to recover quickly from the impacts , is the aim of NN NN , as recently reported by the NNP Commission on NNP . As the Commission explains , investing in NN makes sense from JJ , JJ and ethical perspectives . And as we VBP that NN NN is caused by NNS , society cannot use “ lack of NN ” on its NN as an excuse for inaction any more . text: Discussions of a Green JJ Deal ( GND ) have been all the rage these days , as hundreds of thousands have taken to the streets IN the NN to demand NN on NN NN . RB proposed in 2008 to initiate a comprehensive NN plan to combat NN NN in the UK , the Green NNP Deal ( GND ) has come to JJ attention , gaining particular traction in North NNP . Its vision goes beyond the " green , " " hip , " " vegan , " and " mindful " lifestyle choices of a burgeoning elite JJ class or the tried and failed policies of NN - offsetting , cap and trade , and sustainable development of green capitalism . It proposes definitive steps to VB combat impending NN crises and to give the younger generation hope in the face of rapidly accelerating socio-ecological breakdown and unprecedented inequality . It puts forward a plan to shift the economy away from fossil fuels towards renewable NN ; to eliminate polluting practices in industrial production ; to provide affordable housing for all , free education and NN care ; to create jobs with dignified working conditions and security , and to promote racial , gender and socio-economic equity and justice . But for the GND to work and , indeed , transform the economy and our lives , it must be decolonial . This means , its application must VB hand in hand with a concerted effort to rethink relationships to land , labour , and our collective imaginaries from the structural and historic injustices of Western - style development . The understanding that development policies and ideas rooted in European and North JJ notions of " progress " are destructive and exploitative by their nature must be at the heart of the GND . In seeking to build a JJ economy and another NN of relating to the environment IN us , we must heed the advice of indigenous NNS , in their historical and ongoing demands for cultural autonomy and self - determination , on the NN to restore a diversity of relationships with our environment . What does it mean to be ' green ' ? The GND is meant to halt the loss of biodiversity , the degradation of soils , NN , and rapidly decelerate JJ NN to pre-empt further the catastrophic impacts of NN NN that a failure to stay below CD degrees of NN will bring . To achieve all these things , however , technological fixes , such as NN capture and storage , bound to NN economy forces cannot be the solution . The relationships we must develop with our living environment cannot depend on policies regulated by costly , unpredictable and NN - driven accounting metrics , which defy the speed and severity of the JJ and NN shifts we are experiencing . While all efforts to put the " emergency brake " on ecological degradation are needed , we must recognise the roots of how today 's custodianship and caretaking of land and waters was established and how it is linked to Western notions of development . Our development trajectory has been marred by the idea that NNS are the overlords of the NN , who have to tame nature and submit it to exploitation for their exclusive benefit . It implies that JJ civilisation is somehow separate from nature , whose only role is to provide unlimited resources to feed and expand the JJ material NN . The separation between humanity and nature is RB implied in how environmentalism has been approached in Western societies . It implies that JJ degradation is merely a symptom of bad management in an otherwise non-negotiable JJ development model . The arrogance of this logic is deeply embedded in the mechanisms adopted by the international community to respond to JJ and ecological crises , including its sustainability policies . As RB as we erroneously VBP ourselves as outside and above the rest of the living NN , we will continue to contribute to its destruction . A decolonial GND , therefore , requires repositioning ourselves vis -à - vis nature as an integral part of it - just as JJ indigenous peoples have consistently sought to do in their historical and ongoing struggle for cultural autonomy and self - determination . GND policies must not simply aim to rectify harmful JJ activity that destroys biodiversity , soil fertility , and NN gas pollution but engender a completely JJ approach to producing food , building JJ settlements and meeting JJ needs . Under a decolonial GND , agricultural practices , for example , will have to be completely overhauled . Mass production and distribution will have to be phased out , as should the current practices of optimising yields through monoculture farming . Instead , transitions are required that focus on regenerative agricultural practices to return nutrients to soils ; encourage and recognise NN passed down between generations farming the land ; ensure healthy non-GMO food production that is affordable to all ; and rebuild relationships between producers and consumers . What is so ' JJ ' about it ? The GND must RB adopt a completely JJ approach to the JJ economy . RB , it must recognise that the crises produced by capitalism cannot be solved by capitalism itself . Capitalism , much IN the burning of fossil fuels which feeds it , should rather be phased out and replaced with a diversity of decentralised solidarity economies that put JJ justice and both individual and collective welfare at the core of their mission . A GND can therefore only be " JJ " if it is premised upon a commitment to limiting and redistributing wealth , is oriented towards understanding well - being as sufficiency rather than ceaseless desires and ensures that the means of production are re-localised to transfer decision - making NN to communities at the frontlines of resource extraction . Second , any GND for the NNP North must embrace degrowth , which means scaling down overall material consumption and NN use rather than simply making them more efficient , which MD still expand growth and enable further extraction . It RB means moving society away from wealth accumulation and expansion as a goal in itself and towards wealth distribution and JJ justice . In this sense , changing PRP 's lifestyle choices - buying " green " and eating vegan or organic food - is not a solution to JJ and JJ justice problems . Rather NNS require support systems to radically alter the NN they live and consume . These support systems might involve fostering conditions of solidarity , connection , and joy that are otherwise sapped from the individuality of materialism masquerading as " happiness " . Doing so means that learning to live with what is enough to provide for basic needs and good NN should not be seen as a sacrifice , but as something to gain . This is the JJ step to building a society for everyone , radically JJ than the NN we have now that favours the pursuit of self - enrichment and indulgence . Third , the GND must RB create the conditions for poorer NNS to develop according to their own democratically chosen development path . For that to happen , degrowth policies have to be coupled with decolonisation of the JJ economy . Although the age of colonialism is supposedly over , colonial dynamics still very much dominate relations between the " developed " and the " developing " and determine hegemonic patterns of production and consumption . If the GND does not address the uneven patterns of where production and consumption take place then it threatens to derail " green " or NN - efficient transformations in the JJ South . For example , if the shift to renewable NN is carried out without a parallel decolonisation of trade relations , then NNS IN Bolivia and the Democratic Republic of Congo , rich in coltan , lithium , antimony , nickel and other materials VBN in green technologies , MD still face the dangers of extractivism . RB if measures are taken to ensure that renewable NN production does not contaminate and deplete NN , destroy habitats , and displace communities - hardly likely in any JJ model predicated on optimising outcomes while minimising costs - unequal JJ relations MD doom these NNS to a JJ form of domination VBN as " green colonialism " . A decolonial GND must therefore prioritise restructuring JJ trade relations and reversing the enormous imbalances of cultural , JJ and JJ NN between Western governments and the JJ South . When the prefixes of " green " and " JJ " are removed , we are left with " deal " . This requires understanding what the current " deal " is and why it must be fundamentally restructured . Apart from embracing workers ' rights and progressive JJ policies , a decolonial GND must RB actively interrogate the racial , gender and class supremacies which have ruled the NN and extracted wealth for the benefit of a privileged minority for centuries . This is because , the ongoing and increasingly dire ecological collapse is very much the result of a perverse " JJ contract " in which patriarchy , capitalism and white supremacy shape JJ behaviour . We live in a NN where black , brown , feminine , queer and working - class bodies have faced unthinkable acts of violent dehumanisation under the banner of contemporary Western development . This NN of making and shaping the NN and its inhabitants has not gone away with the introduction of symbolic laws forbidding discrimination . It remains fundamental to the socio- JJ relations which dominate our lives and which tie ecological destruction and racialised cheap labour to the maintenance of uneven relations of trade across the NN . Take historical plantations as an example . The production of commodities IN sugar and cotton involved both the brutal enslavement of NNS and the ruthless abuse of the environment , which led to severe deforestation , soil erosion and habitat destruction . The goods extracted through violent exploitation of both NNS and nature were then sold for the benefit of wealthy white settler colonialists . This plantation model has not fundamentally changed since slavery was officially abolished . It has rather become more sophisticated with the liberalisation of the economy and the advent of digital technology which today ensures greater predictability and NN in yields , labour hours and profits . Today , agriculture and other sectors IN the NN are still dependent on a largely racialised and marginalised labour force , coerced in myriad ways to accept harsh working conditions . And again the outcomes are the same : destruction of the environment and ever - burgeoning profit for a select few . A decolonial GND must break the bonds of the plantation model of JJ relations by introducing a JJ " JJ contract " rooted in ethical and JJ commitment to JJ , racial and gender justice . It must seek to establish a completely JJ set of rules for socio- JJ relations in our society - CD VBN on acceptance , respect for JJ NN and dignity , solidarity , and equity . Under a decolonial GND , temporary , underpaid employment will be discontinued . Job creation will be generated by the JJ transformation away from fossil fuels and overexploitation of resources and towards worker - owned renewable NN and the relocalisation of industry that puts collective interests over individual ones . Jobs will have to pay enough for the employee to sustain a dignified NN ; they will have to provide JJ security and desirable working conditions that are free of abuse and discrimination and stimulate creativity . Worker - owned cooperatives MD be CD model to follow to create jobs and provide various community services , from NN care and NN care to recycling and security . However , this will only work if cooperatives are themselves embedded in globally decolonised economies geared towards responsible relations between NNS and the land . A decolonial GND must RB recognise and seek to compensate for the ills that centuries of racial , gender and JJ oppression have produced . It must , therefore , pay special attention to historically marginalised groups and indigenous communities dispossessed of their lands and ways of knowing and being . As part of this transformation , it should RB make provisions for reparations for colonial injustices . Thus , I suggest three organising principles for a decolonial GND : 1 ) " VBG green " must rethink and experiment in alternative JJ relationships to each other and to non-humans , rooted in reciprocity and responsibility . 2 ) The NN economy must be reoriented towards principles of degrowth , decolonisation and relocalisation 3 ) The unequal NN relations underlying the " JJ contract " of Western development models must be democratised to eliminate discrimination and racial supremacy in all its forms . For a GND to work however , it can not be limited to discussions and NN within the borders of a single country or region . The dehumanising and ecologically destructive forces of capitalism have proven to adhere to no borders , so any response strategies under a GND must have a JJ scope . A GND requires collective commitment to resist oppressive forces that are literally waging a NN against a good NN for all . This means JJ resistance and NN in the streets , each in their own NN responding to the induced austerity policies of NN and NN that together reinforce the " JJ contract " responsible for ecological collapse . At the same NN , " decolonial " cannot be another prefix to tack on along with " green " and " JJ " to make a status - quo development " deal " appear more inclusive . It must recognise both the JJ NN of Western development models in organising NNS and nature in violent ways , but RB more regional and historically - specific variants . These MD include the subjugation of NNS and their relationships to the land in places IN Kashmir or West Papua and the rising demonisation of indigenous worldviews in Brazil and Bolivia . A decolonial GND requires constant learning , building mutual consent and trust , and self - reflection of the embedded thought processes and habitus patterns that we all hold in contributing to such oppression , whether we realise it or not . We have reached a point of no return and we must realise that there is no saviour and no quick - fix solution for the NN catastrophe we currently face . While the " mess " we are in was not created by all of humanity equally ( and we must recognise this ! ) , it is a " mess " of such proportions that we VBP committed and unconditional solidarity to VB ourselves out of it . The views expressed in this article are the author 's own and do not necessarily reflect NNP Jazeera 's editorial stance .

( Lauren Radack / San Diego Gas & Electric via AP ) NNP NNP ( AP ) — As JJ NNS creep higher and the NN of deadly wildfires grows , utilities in the West are struggling to respond to the threat . San Diego Gas & Electric was ahead of the curve when it began strengthening its wildfire prediction and electricity distribution systems a decade ago . At the NN , some of its decisions were unpopular . But now , while its northern neighbor Pacific Gas & Electric confronts a so - called NN NN bankruptcy after its equipment sparked the deadliest wildfire in NN history , the Southern California NN is viewed as a model for how utilities as far - flung as Australia can prepare for the worst impacts of NN NN . SDG&E invested $ 1.5 CD over a decade swapping wood poles for steel , hiring meteorologists , deploying helicopters with infrared inspection capabilities and building a sophisticated NN monitoring NN with mountaintop cameras and about 200 stations which capture 200,000 NN - related NN points daily . Caroline Winn , chief operating officer , was at SDG&E when its equipment sparked a deadly wildfire in 2007 , and she was CD of thousands to evacuate her home . She reflected on how the NN ’s culture changed after the disaster and how executives ’ attitudes about the role NN NNS play in NN NN has shifted dramatically . The conversation has been edited for clarity and length . Q : What prompted San Diego Gas & Electric to invest so heavily in overhauling its operations to reduce the NN of wildfires ? A : Our journey began over a decade ago when the San Diego region RB experienced the unprecedented levels of destruction from firestorms in October of 2007 . Those fires were among the most destructive in California history at that NN . Unfortunately , there were lives lost and there were hundreds of structures , including those that belong to our employees , that were damaged or lost , and RB 500,000 acres were scorched . On that day , we knew that the National NNP Service had called for a red flag event , but that ’s about all we knew . So when the fires broke out , we were RB in a reactive mode . It affected so JJ of us in this NN on such a personal level that ... keeping our infrastructure from causing any fires became this rallying call across the NN . We RB shifted from being focused on keeping the lights on — because that was RB our main focus — to the most important attribute becoming keeping our communities safe . There was n’t a prescriptive plan that existed in terms of how we should design , engineer , construct or maintain our infrastructure against the increasing threat of violent fires . There was n’t a blueprint on how to develop and build out what MD become CD of our largest utility - owned NN networks . Back in 2007 the belief in NN NN was n’t what it is today . But CD thing was RB clear to us : we experienced NN conditions that we had never experienced in previous decades . Q : Your NN began proactively shutting off the NN to reduce wildfire risks in 2013 . How did customers react initially and how was that changed ? A : It was RB met with fierce opposition from the NN . We were the JJ utility to do this and NNS did n’t understand why we had to turn off the NN for JJ safety . Despite the harsh criticism , we stayed the course . We held town halls after the shutoff so that the community MD understand the type of conditions we were experiencing . But RB it was important for us to listen to what our customers needed during these types of experiences . Acceptance of the NN shut - offs is significantly better than it was in 2013 . We VBP very few complaints because I VBP they understand why we do it , and how we do it , in that our goal is RB to keep our communities safe . Q : How does SDG&E VB NNS with limited financial resources tolerate blackouts ? A : We have partnered with the food banks and Meals on Wheels so they ’re able to provide necessities to the more vulnerable customers , whether they ’re income - qualifying customers or they have mobility issues or they ’re seniors . We RB , since 2007 , grew deep relationships with these organizations because that is our NN to VB every customer through these situations . Q : What are the most important things utilities must do to prepare for NN NN ? A : I VBP about it in terms of our efforts to reduce NN gas NNS . We ’ve installed over 3,000 electric vehicle charging stations in areas that do n’t have as much access to electric vehicle charging ... and 45 % of our electricity that we provide to customers comes from the NN and the wind . NN NN is impacting the wildfire threat , but RB the CO2 ( NN dioxide ) and NNS of wildfires are tremendous . So if we can VB a chance of ensuring that these wildfires , if they happen , stay JJ and that utility infrastructure is not the NN of it , then we RB feel that we are leaning in ... and we ’re adapting very aggressively and progressively .

text: The Arctic has warmed more than the rest of the NN , and its NN cover has thinned and shrunk . text: The relationship between JJ activities and NN NN , involving both causes as well as impacts , has become a major issue of concern and interest all over the NN . The Fourth Assessment Report ( AR4 ) of the Intergovernmental Panel on NNP NNP informs us that the atmospheric concentration of CO has increased from 280 ppm in the period 1000 – 1750 AD to 379 ppm in the NN 2005 . The terrestrial biospheric exchange had been a cumulative source of about 30 Gt C for the past CD centuries but acted as a sink in the 1990s . The concentration of methane in the atmosphere has more than doubled from 700 ppb in the period 1000 – 1750 AD , to reach a concentration of 1774 ppb in the NN 2005 . The concentrations of hydrofluorocarbons , perfluorocarbons , SF and N O have RB increased . The tropospheric concentration of ozone has increased RB though its stratospheric concentration has decreased . The rising NNS and concentrations of all these gases have led to numerous NNS in JJ NN variables . The JJ mean NN NN is very likely to have increased by 0.74±0.18 °C during the hundred NN period 1906 – 2005 . Although the increase is spread out all over the globe , it is greater in the northern hemisphere , and land areas have warmed faster than the oceans . It is very likely that the number of hot days and hot nights has increased and the number of cold days , cold nights and frost has decreased for nearly all land areas . The continental precipitation has increased in the eastern parts of North and South NNP , northern Europe and central Asia . However , it has decreased in some regions of Africa , southern Asia and the Mediterranean . It is RB likely that the area affected by drought has increased since 1970 .

text: VB breaking NN alerts and special reports . The NN and stories that matter , delivered weekday mornings . Catch a glimpse of Katy Ayers paddling her canoe on a Nebraska lake this summer and you might do a double take . At JJ glance , her 8 - NN vessel looks much IN any other canoe — same oblong shape , same pointed ends , same ability to float on NN . But upon closer inspection , it ’s clearly anything but ordinary : Ayers ’ canoe is made out of mushrooms . More specifically , her boat is made from mycelium , the dense , fibrous roots of the mushroom that typically live beneath the soil . Ayers , 28 , a student at Central Community College in Columbus , Nebraska , RB gave her creation a fitting name : “ Myconoe . ” Though Ayers has taken the canoe out for several quasi- recreational excursions — and plans to do so again as soon as the NN warms up in the rural part of Nebraska where she lives — her real goal with the eye - catching project is to raise broader awareness about mushrooms . She is part of a growing movement of mushroom advocates , NNS who VBP these squishy , sometimes edible fungi can VB solve some of our most pressing JJ problems . In addition to their ability to break down harmful pollutants and chemicals , Ayers pointed out that mushrooms can be VBN for everything from household insulation to furniture to packaging , replacing plastics , Styrofoam and other materials that are hard to recycle and harmful to the environment . “ Mushrooms are here to VB us — they ’re a gift , ” Ayers VBD . “ There ’s so much we can do with them beyond just food ; it ’s so limitless . They ’re our biggest ally for helping the environment . ” Mushrooms are n't exactly mainstream , though citizen NNS IN Ayers and some private NNS hope to someday VB that . The NNP NNP - VBN biotech NN Ecovative Design , for instance , has made headlines for its mushroom - VBN packaging material , which has been deployed by NNS such as Ikea and Dell . Mushrooms are being VBN at the local level to VB clean up toxic debris and contaminated soil — a process VBN as mycoremediation — but so far have not been adopted on a larger scale . Ayers never paid much attention to mushrooms until she enrolled in 2018 at the college in Columbus , a JJ city with RB 23,000 residents . During her JJ semester , an English instructor challenged students to find and VB a potential solution to NN NN . During her research , Ayers came across a 2013 documentary called “ Super Fungi , ” which made the NN for mushrooms as an JJ ally and highlighted some of their innovative uses . Ayers was sold on the NN of mushrooms instantly . Having learned that mycelium is buoyant and waterproof , she decided to try VBG it to create a boat . “ I always have very JJ ideas , ” she VBD . “ So I VBP something and it ’s JJ and I just VBP to make it bigger and better . Since I ’m from Nebraska , I love to fish . I ’ve always wanted a boat . Why not just grow it ? ” With a mini -grant from the college , Ayers got to work . She reached out to a mushroom NN in nearby Grand Island for NN , sharing her idea with owner Ash Gordon . He agreed to VB immediately and offered her a summer internship so she MD learn the ins and outs of fungi . During the day , Ayers worked alongside Gordon at Nebraska Mushroom , doing lab work , creating spawn and harvesting , packaging and processing mushrooms . After finishing their work for the day , the CD turned their attention to the canoe project . They RB built a wooden skeleton and a hammock - JJ structure to suspend the boat - shaped form in the air . They next sandwiched the boat ’s skeleton with mushroom spawn and let nature take over . For CD weeks , the fledgling canoe hung inside a special growing room in Gordon ’s facility , where NNS ranged between 80 and 90 degrees and the humidity hovered between 90 to 100 percent . The last step in the process was to let the 100 - pound boat dry in the Nebraska NN . All VBN , Ayers VBD she spent $ 500 on spawn , tools and equipment to build the canoe . Ayers , who displayed her “ Myconoe ” at the 2019 Nebraska NNP Fair , has taken the canoe out for three test floats , including CD in which CD NNS comfortably sat inside . The boat is still alive , which means it fruits — grows mushrooms — each NN they take it out for a paddle . The successful mycelium canoe inspired Ayers and Gordon to experiment with making chairs , landscaping bricks and other items . Though it started as a hands - on learning opportunity for Ayers in the course of her collegiate studies , the canoe has RB served as a quirky conduit for conversations about mushrooms . “ It ’s not just a piece of art , this is a functioning boat that works , ” Gordon , 39 , VBD . “ It RB helps bridge that gap between NNS who did n’t have an interest in mushrooms — maybe they do n’t VB to eat mushrooms and RB have n’t thought about other potential uses for them . The boat gave them something to look at and VB about . ” Now Ayers is sharing her newfound fungi fabrication NN with other students at the community college . She ’s part of Growing Pathways to STEM , a full - ride scholarship program funded by the National NNP Foundation that aims to VB low - income and underserved undergraduates studying NN , technology , engineering and math . Ayers is leading CD of the cohort ’s main research projects : building bee hotels , JJ structures RB called nests or homes , from mycelium . Inspired by research from NNP NNP NNP , which VBD that honeybees who consumed mycelium extract had lower levels of a harmful NN , Ayers and her classmates hope to better understand the effects of mycelium on Nebraska ’s solitary bees . Though the community college closed all campus buildings in early April to prevent the spread of the NN , Ayers is keeping the project alive in her basement while taking JJ classes . In addition to her full - NN course load , Ayers works as the community college ’s sustainability intern , keeping tabs on NN use across the community college NN ’s seven campuses and centers . The internship , which Ayers has RB been able to continue remotely , and self - led mushroom research projects are just the start : After graduating with an associate ’s degree in NN , Ayers plans to earn a bachelor ’s degree in biology and , later , a doctorate in mycology . And after that ? Save the NN . “ She has an innate desire to VB the NN , ” VBD Lauren Gillespie , a biological sciences instructor at Central Community College and Ayers ’ adviser . “ She believes that she can do it , and I VBP that she can do it . ”

text: Takeda predicts that NN NN will VB its Zika and dengue fever NNS find a larger NN . Roche VBZ it MD ultimately make it attractive for the NN to develop treatments for diseases IN malaria . And AbbVie VBZ extreme NN events might boost its immunology NNS . But the potential risks of NN NN — and the attendant increase in natural disasters — stand to outstrip any of those incremental gains , as the NNS described in recent NN assessment reports to the British nonprofit CDP . Hurricanes and superstorms , NN outages and flooding all threaten manufacturing facilities and research sites , particularly when animals are involved . Droughts , too , threaten critical NN supplies . Forest fires , RB if remote from a given plant or research facility , bring smoke and air pollution that can similarly disrupt the day - to - day work for drug makers and their supply chain . Geography does n’t VB , either . The biotech and pharmaceutical industries — concentrated , as they are , in coastal areas IN Boston , NNP Jersey , and California — MD face higher risks for extreme NN events . STAT surveyed the NN assessment plans for more than a dozen major pharmaceutical NNS and spoke with officials at labs that survived extreme NN events and others who are planning to avoid their repercussions . All emphasized that the risks are already real — and underscored how hard the industry is working to prepare to meet the challenge . “ You RB start to VB to ask yourself and sort of reverse - engineer — what are you at NN to , what can you tolerate as a community , as an asset or a structure , ” VBD William Sweet , an oceanographer with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration , speaking specifically about the impact of RB a JJ rise in NN level in places prone to flooding . “ Vulnerabilities that are exposed by today ’s events , it ’s important to document because those likely are VBG to be the same area that VBP exposed and are vulnerable . ” In the last five NNS alone , extreme NN has caused massive disruptions in the pharmaceutical and biotech industries . Hurricanes and flooding can wipe out research and manufacturing facilities , smoke and air pollution from forest fires threaten experiments and lab animals — as do frigid NNS and NN outages . And the gradual rise in average NNS have some concerned that plants and animals that serve as sources of existing and potential JJ drugs MD vanish . Pfizer , for example , estimates it lost $ 195 CD in inventory and overhead when three Puerto Rico manufacturing facilities were wiped out by the recent devastating hurricane season . Eli Lilly ran its Puerto Rico facility with emergency diesel generators “ for months ” after the storm . For some , Hurricane Maria was a wake - up call . To AstraZeneca , the storm “ showed the site was not resilient enough . ” The NN is planning to invest more in weatherproof buildings “ for current and future conditions . ” AbbVie spent a few thousand dollars securing the roofs on its manufacturing plants on the island . Wildfires , too , can have an extreme impact — RB if they occur further afield . For more than a week in November , wildfires in California sent enough JJ particles into the air that it became “ unhealthy ” for residents to breathe without filters — and MD have damaged the air filters that research labs do use . “ The R&D that fuels innovative activity in NN sciences NNS requires conditions that are tightly controlled , particularly when it comes to air quality , NN , and other NN settings , ” VBD Will Zasadny , the California NNP Sciences Association ’s communications director . In addition to issues IN the NN grid and the impact the fires had on employees , he VBD , “ wildfire smoke is damaging on air filtration systems . ” Recent experiences at CD research facilities — CD in NNP NNP and CD in Texas — RB VBP illustrate the potential pitfalls for earlier - stage NN NN research — as well as the promise for facilities that prepare for extreme NN in advance . When Hurricane Sandy hit NNP NNP City in 2012 , some of the facilities at NYU Langone , an academic JJ center with a hospital and research facilities , flooded and lost NN — including CD of its animal care facilities . As some NNS carried out NN - sensitive samples in bins filled with dry NN , others delivered NN to the center ’s aquariums and evacuated the mice and rats that they MD . Not all of the research animals made it out . According to a National Academies of NNP report on disaster resilience , 35,000 mice — which represented about $ 25 CD and about CD - third of the NN ’s total mouse population — died . “ In a NN , the NN are the ones who lost , ” VBD Jennifer Pullium , the director of NYU Langone ’s division of laboratory animal resources . “ The purpose of these animals is for biomedical research — to improve the quality of NN and NN of NNS . When progress is set back , progress for NNS is set back . ” IN JJ places affected by a disaster , NYU Langone planned to rebuild itself without the same soft spots . That meant installing JJ flood barricades and moving critical things IN generators and computers up to higher floors — but RB making non-flood related modifications , IN making sure the NN ’s hospitals had air conditioners hooked up to the emergency NN network . “ Something IN [ Sandy ] RB does VB crystallize and motivate a lot of NN and a lot of thinking that MD n’t happen otherwise , ” VBD Paul Schwabacher , NYU Langone ’s senior vice NN of facilities management . “ It did allow us to make a lot of NNS and improve things beyond what we ’d been planning at the NN . ” Langone ’s JJ defenses have n’t been tested yet . But Baylor College of Medicine ’s response to 2017 ’s Hurricane Harvey shows that good preparation should pay off . The college lost thousands of research animals in Tropical Storm Allison in 2001 — and spent $ 35 CD afterward on better flood defenses , including food NNS and pumps . When Hurricane Harvey hit in 2017 — a Category 4 hurricane that was CD of the costliest Atlantic storms ever — the college was ready . Baylor had a “ ride out ” team of 52 NNS , including some dedicated to taking care of the JJ school ’s 100,000 animals while the campus was flooded . None died . Most of the major biotech and pharmaceutical NNS have been preparing for NN NN for NNS . Johnson & Johnson and Novo Nordisk scored an A rating from CDP ; Sanofi , Pfizer , Roche , Novartis , Merck , Eli Lilly , Takeda , and Biogen all scored an A minus . GlaxoSmithKline and AbbVie earned B ratings , and Amgen and Bristol - Myers Squibb got C’s . The ratings are VBN on the NN ’s awareness and management of NN NN issues . The size and type of their investments in those preparations vary . Johnson & Johnson , for example , wrote in its report that it underwent a full - blown review of its NN scarcity activities after a drought affected its facilities in Cape Town , South Africa . Biogen poured $ 500,000 into JJ software to monitor its supply chain after hurricanes and storms affected CD of its major locations . Amgen highlighted its efforts to reduce NN use , spotlighting a facility that now reuses about 74 percent of the treated wastewater it generates to cool its manufacturing equipment . In Cambridge , Mass . ’s legendary Kendall Square , CD local real estate developer has already worked to ensure that a third of the facilities it manages there are prepared for extreme NN events all the NN up through 2050 or further . Those preparations are necessary in part because of where Kendall Square sits . A short walk from the Charles River , the biotech hub already faces a JJ flood NN from major storms . According to a recent city report , JJ issues MD start to crop up soon . By 2050 , the NN IN Boston should be a NN or CD higher than it was in 2000 — so high that the city ’s report on NN NN vulnerability VBZ the dams that separate the rivers IN the city from Massachusetts Bay MD be pretty useless . If a once - in - a - decade storm hits , winds might blow the NN up from the pond or river — a storm surge — or NN might come back up from drainage pipes . Alexandria Real Estate has over 4.3 CD square NNS of office NN in Kendall Square . That includes at least 1.9 CD square NNS of brand - JJ NN built with NN NN in NN . Gone are basement electrical rooms and NN centers — they ’ve been moved up to the JJ floor . Thresholds for JJ - floor doors , too , are all above the point the city ’s reports suggest NN might ultimately rise if a major storm hits after the NN levels IN the city have risen by a NN or CD . Yet the real estate NN ’s not - inconsiderable NN mostly stops at the thresholds of their own buildings . The NN ca n’t stop a street from flooding or make sure the city ’s drains wo n’t become overwhelmed with stormwater . Developers in Kendall have tried ; among other things , Alexandria and others have paid for a JJ stormwater drain that can take up to 630,000 gallons of stormwater . CD thing that Alexandria and others can do — and have done — is ensure that their buildings wo n’t make flooding worse . Some Alexandria - owned buildings have equipment on the roofs that can store stormwater for a while before its released — slowly — to the street ; each site RB has a NN in place to encourage rain to drain into the ground RB , not into the streets . And specialized valves prevent sewer backups from bringing that NN into a building . ( RB the toilets will still work without adding to the sewer ’s problems , at least for a day . ) “ We ’re confident that our tenants and our properties here in Kendall Square are well - protected from NN NN vulnerabilities IN flooding , ” Andrews VBD . There are less tangible risks to consider , too : the prospect that if a NN ’s approach to NN NN is too timid , it MD be harder to recruit talented employees in an industry where sterling job applicants often have the upper hand . “ As a NN - VBN NN focused on improving the quality of NN , stakeholders MD set expectations related to Biogen ’s efforts towards NN NN , ” the NN stated — adding that if they fail to meet those expectations , potential employees MD VB elsewhere . “ Loss of highly - qualified employees to competitors due to falling short of expectations MD place Biogen ’s research and development efforts at NN . ” Merck ’s report puts a more positive spin on the issue . “ We recognize that our policies and actions IN JJ and JJ issues such as our NN footprint can VB attract and attain talent , ” the NN wrote . Yet to some , CD industry alone ca n’t make up for a broader failure to act . “ It MD seem that , you VBP , as a nation , we should be doing much more to try to mitigate these risks . They ’re just tremendous , and I do n’t VB we ’ve reflected on the cost of NN NN and other risks that are coming , ” VBD NYU ’s Schwabacher . “ We MD be doing more — should be doing more . ”

text: ime for something IN panic : last week the UN NN talks in Madrid essentially collapsed , RB as NNS were reporting that the 2010s had been by far the hottest decade since records began . Most of the blame fell on NNS IN the U.S. , Brazil , and Saudi Arabia , but IN the NN JJ systems simply are n’t responding to the greatest NN they ’ve ever faced — they ’re so corrupted by fossil fuel NN , so overcome by inertia , so preoccupied with the next NN or coup . But , amid the desolation , there were a couple of signs of hope . They came from the NN of high finance . Just as young NNS and indigenous leaders were being kicked out of the UN talks for their protests , the Liberty Mutual insurance NN became CD of the JJ JJ U.S. insurers to announce it MD stop aiding coal NNS . The announcement came after sustained pressure from a coalition of JJ groups called Insure Our Future , and though Liberty ’s pledges are just a beginning — oil and gas are the bigger future threats at this point , as coal ’s decline is already underway — it was proof that RB vast sums of NN can’t insulate NNS from activism . That point was underscored over when Goldman Sachs announced on December 14 that it MD restrict its lending to the coal industry , and further that it was n’t interested in funding the drilling of the Arctic . Again a coalition of groups — from the Gwich ’in tribe in Alaska ’s Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to the Sierra Club and the Rainforest NNP Network — had pressed hard . And again Goldman ’s response was just a JJ step . But given the imbalance in forces — a remote native band against CD of the NN ’s biggest banks — it was a hopeful sign . Hopeful because these kinds of campaigns are VBG to expand and build . But if these financial giants begin to move , the effects will be both quick and JJ — and those are the CD things most required for effective progress on the NN . Chase Bank exemplifies the problem : they ’re the worst , lending hundreds of billions of dollars for the most extreme fossil fuel projects on NN . If these bankers plugged the NN pipeline , the fossil fuel industry MD have to stop expanding — which is precisely what NNS have VBN us is now required . But look at them another NN : unlike Exxon or Shell , they ’re able to make plenty of NN from things other than fossil fuel . Destroying the NN is only a side business for them — heck , they MD make NN financing the transition to NN and wind . And they ’re potentially vulnerable to citizen anger . Activists , more and more , are taking up the cry of “ Make Them Pay , ” understanding that it ’s not okay to pile up profits by devastating the NN . Chase has 5,000 branches spread across NNP . Indigenous activists joined by my colleagues at the 350 Seattle chapter shut down all 44 branches in their city for a day last spring , and there ’s no reason not to try the same thing across the country . The JJ and the financial are not completely separate tracks for activists , of course . The European Investment Bank announced earlier this autumn that it MD no longer finance fossil fuel projects ; campaigners in Switzerland VBD December 16 that they were getting closer to persuading the Swiss Central Bank to take NN ( and Swiss banks are no JJ thing ! ) . But the truly JJ NN is piled up in those JJ institutions that dominate JJ finance . That dominance is not fair nor wise , but RB now it gives us CD more lever to reach for in this moment of NN NN .

text: FILE - In this March 26 , 2014 file photo , BlackRock Chairman and CEO Laurence Fink is interviewed by Maria Bartiromo on Fox Business Network 's " Opening Bell with Maria Bartiromo , " in NNP NNP . ( AP Photo / Mark Lennihan , File ) FILE - In this March 26 , 2014 file photo , BlackRock Chairman and CEO Laurence Fink is interviewed by Maria Bartiromo on Fox Business Network 's " Opening Bell with Maria Bartiromo , " in NNP NNP . BlackRock , the NN 's largest asset manager , is making NN NN central to its investment decisions VBG forward . Fink , who oversees the management of about $ 7 trillion in funds , VBD in his influential annual letter to CEOs Tuesday , Jan. 14 , 2020 , that he believes we are “ on the edge of a fundamental reshaping of finance ” because of a NN NN . ( AP Photo / Mark Lennihan , File ) NNP NNP ( AP ) — A changing NN means dramatic risks for the NN — and for investments too , the chief of the NN ’s largest investment manager VBD Tuesday . To prepare for and protect against those risks , BlackRock CEO Laurence Fink VBD in his influential annual letter to CEOs that his firm , which manages roughly $ 7 trillion for investors , will make a series of moves putting NN NN and sustainability at the center of its investing approach . Among them , BlackRock will cut out investments in some coal producers from some of its portfolios , sharply increase the number of sustainability - focused funds that it offers , and vote against NNS at shareholder meetings when they ’re too slow in disclosing and mitigating their impact on the environment . “ NN NN has become a defining factor in NNS ’ JJ - term prospects , ” Fink wrote in his letter , adding that he believes “ we are on the edge of a fundamental reshaping of finance ” because of it . Fink predicted that the NNS in how capital is deployed will come “ more quickly than we VBP NNS to the NN itself , ” and “ sooner than most anticipate . ” In fact , the shift is already underway . Investors poured a net $ 20.6 CD into sustainable funds across the industry last NN , nearly quadruple the record set a NN earlier , according to Morningstar . Investors , particularly younger ones , increasingly VBP they VBP their NN invested with an eye toward sustainability . The total dollars are still JJ relative to the entire industry — investors plugged a total of $ 413.9 CD into all taxable bond funds last NN , while yanking $ 41.3 CD out of all U.S. NN funds — but the trend is clear and accelerating . Fearful of losing out on those dollars — and the fees that they produce — investment NNS are rushing to meet the surging demand . BlackRock and other huge asset managers are generally behind smaller competitors when it comes to sustainability , VBD Danielle Fugere , NN of shareholder - advocacy group As You Sow . BlackRock , NNP Street , Vanguard and others have been criticized for not doing more about the environment . Besides protests outside its Manhattan headquarters , BlackRock has RB heard criticism from members of Congress who VBP it MD better address NN NN . Because of its size and reach , any shift in focus by BlackRock MD alter the industry . It is a major shareholder in thousands of NNS through its popular exchange - traded funds that track various indexes , as well as its funds run by NN - picking managers . But Fugere VBD Tuesday ’s announcement is only a JJ step . “ The words are significant , and the words show leadership , ” Fugere VBD . “ But that ’s not enough . We have to VB on the ground NN , and we VBP to VB it quickly . There is no NN . Australia is burning up . California is burning up . ” The wildfires in parts of Australia and California and other recent disasters have shown JJ institutional investors that NN NN is just as much a threat to their returns in the near term as over the coming decades . “ The physical risks have become so immediately clear and stark , ” VBD Amy Borrus , deputy director of the Council for Institutional Investors , whose members include pension funds , endowments and other U.S. - VBN asset owners investing more than $ 4 trillion . “ JJ institutional investors will welcome these steps by BlackRock , ” she VBD . “ More and more JJ funds are coming RB to the view that sound JJ , JJ and governance practices are not just about making the NN better but about fundamentally creating and preserving shareholder value . ” This approach to investing comes after a yearslong evolution for the industry , which began with simple funds that bluntly excluded stocks deemed as harmful , such as gun makers or tobacco stocks . Now , fund managers VBP they they look at JJ , JJ and governance issues broadly as part of their analysis of any investment . It ’s VBN as “ ESG ” investing , and proponents VBP it aids investors ’ returns , not just their consciences , because it helps them avoid risky stocks and JJ potential losses . NNS with poor records on JJ issues are more likely to face JJ fines , for example . For all the noise made by Fink ’s announcement , the reaction in the NN NN was muted on Tuesday . NN stocks in the S&P 500 were down , but not as much as some other corners of the NN . Coal stocks were mixed . In his letter , Fink VBD NNS and investors have a role to play in the transition to a low - NN NN , but governments will ultimately VB to lead the NN . Some movement has begun . The European Union on Tuesday unveiled a plan to dedicate a quarter of its budget to tackling NN NN and to VB shift 1 trillion euros ( $ 1.1 trillion ) in investment towards making the economy more environmentally friendly over the next CD NNS . The Europe Investment Plan will be funded by the EU budget and the private sector . It aims to deliver on European Commission NN Ursula von der Leyen ’s Green Deal to make the bloc the NN ’s JJ NN - neutral continent by 2050 . “ It will be interesting to VB whether Black Rock ’s high profile move will have any impact on policy , ” Borrus VBD . “ NN can do much more in the JJ run on NN NN than investment flows . ” AP Reporter Samuel Petrequin contributed to this report from Brussels .

text: As I report on NN NN , I come across a lot of scary facts , IN the possibility that thawing permafrost in Siberia MD release gigatons of NN dioxide into the atmosphere or the NN that Greenland MD pass a tipping point and begin to melt rapidly . To do that , we VBP to reduce JJ NN NNS ( which hit about CD CD tons last NN ) until they are equal to or less than the amount of NN sequestered by the oceans and plant NN ( which removed about 4.8 CD tons of NN last NN ) . Yet almost all of the subjects in Sterman 's NN failed to realize that , assuming instead that you MD stabilize NN concentration simply by capping NN NNS at their current level . That 's not the NN  and in fact , pursuing such a plan for the future MD virtually guarantee that JJ NN MD spin out of NN . But it 's not  we can't " wait and VB " on JJ NN because the NN has a momentum all its own , and if we wait for decades to finally act to reduce NN NNS , it MD well be too late . text: Drowned cities ; stagnant seas ; intolerable heatwaves ; entire nations uninhabitable … and more than 11 CD NNS . A four - degree - warmer NN is the stuff of nightmares and yet that ’s where we ’re heading in just decades . While governments mull various NN targets aimed at keeping JJ - induced JJ heating within safe levels – including JJ ambitions to reach net - zero NNS by 2050 – it ’s worth looking ahead pragmatically at what happens if we fail . After all , JJ NNS VBP it ’s highly unlikely that we will stay below 2C ( above pre-industrial levels ) by the end of the century , let alone 1.5C . Most NNS are not making anywhere near enough progress to meet these internationally agreed targets . NN models predict we ’re currently on track for a heating of somewhere between 3C and 4C for 2100 , although bear in NN that these are JJ average NNS – at the poles and over land ( where NNS live ) , the increase MD be double that . Predictions are tricky , however , as NNS depend on how sensitive the NN is to NN dioxide ( CO ) . Most models assume that it is not very sensitive – that ’s where the lower 3C comes from – but a whole JJ set of models to be published in 2021 finds much greater sensitivity . They put heating at RB 5C by the end of the century , meaning NNS MD be experiencing as much as 10C of heating over land . Such uncertainty is n’t ideal , but for our purposes let ’s plump for an entirely feasible planetary heating of 4C by the end of the century . If that seems a JJ NN away , consider that plenty of NNS you VBP will be RB then . My NNS will be in their 80s , perhaps with middle - aged NNS and grandchildren . It might RB sound pleasant , IN retiring from the UK to southern Spain . The last NN the NN was this hot was 15 m NNS ago during the miocene , when intense volcanic eruptions in western North NNP emitted vast quantities of CO . We ’re looking at vast dead zones in the oceans as nutrients from fertiliser runoff combine with warmer waters to produce an explosion in algae that starve marine NN of oxygen . To the south and north of this humid zone , bands of expansive desert will RB rule out agriculture and JJ habitation . Some models predict that desert conditions will stretch from the Sahara RB up through south and central Europe , drying rivers including the Danube and the Rhine . In South NNP , the picture is more complicated : increased precipitation MD enhance the Amazon rainforest , leading to mightier river flow . Other models predict a weakening of the easterlies over the Atlantic , drying the Amazon , increasing fires and turning it from forest to grassland . The tipping point for the Amazon MD well be triggered by deforestation ; while the intact forest MD cope with some drought because it generates and maintains its own moist ecosystem , areas that have been opened up through degradation allow moisture to escape . “ A combination of NN NN and deforestation MD push it into a savannah NN , ” Rockström VBZ . This is undoubtedly a more hostile , dangerous NN for humanity , which by 2100 will number RB 11 CD , all of whom will VB food , NN , NN and somewhere to live . It will be , in a giant understatement , problematic . The good NN is that NNS wo n’t become extinct – the NNS can survive with just a few hundred individuals ; the bad NN is , we VBP great loss of NN and perhaps the end of our civilisations . JJ of the places where NNS live and grow food will no longer be suitable for either . Yet by 2100 , most of the low and mid latitudes will be uninhabitable because of heat stress or drought ; despite stronger precipitation , the hotter soils will lead to faster evaporation and most populations will struggle for fresh NN . We will have to live on a smaller land NN with a larger population . Rockström does n’t VB our chances . “ It ’s difficult to VB how we MD accommodate eight CD NNS or maybe RB half of that , ” he VBZ . “ There will be a rich minority of NNS who survive with modern lifestyles , no doubt , but it will be a turbulent , conflict - ridden NN . ” He points out that we already use nearly half the NN ’s NN - free NN to produce food for 7 CD NNS and thinks meeting the needs of 11 CD in such hostile conditions MD be impossible . “ The reason is primarily making enough food , but RB we MD have lost the biodiversity we ’re dependent on and be facing a cocktail of negative shocks all the NN , from fires to droughts . ” Others are more sanguine . “ I do n’t VB that NNS as a NN or RB industrial civilisation is seriously threatened , ” VBZ Ken Caldeira , climatologist at the Carnegie Institution for NNP in California . “ NNS live in Houston , Miami and Atlanta because they live in air conditioning through the hot summers . If NNS are rich enough to air - condition their lives , they can watch whatever is the successor to Game of Thrones on TV , as the natural NN decays IN them , ” he VBZ . Heat - tolerant , drought - resistant crop varieties , such as cassava and millet , will replace JJ of our current unmodified staples such as rice and wheat and they will grow faster and with greater NN efficiency because of the high CO levels . This means we MD grow crops through the winter months , hydroponically in smaller spaces , stacked up in warehouses or RB underground , leaving valuable land surfaces for other uses . ” Cultivation of algal mats and crops grown on floating platforms and in marshland MD RB contribute , while crops MD potentially be grown in uninhabitable regions , farmed and processed remotely by artificial farmers . text: A warmer NN means more and greater extremes in destructive and dangerous NN , such as heat waves , wildfires , droughts , flooding , and violent storms . There were 70 tropical cyclones or hurricanes in the Northern Hemisphere in 2018 , compared with the JJ - term average of 53 . Powerful and often record - breaking storms brought devastation to the Mariana Islands , Philippines , Vietnam , Korea , and Tonga . In the U.S. , hurricanes Florence and Michael caused huge JJ damage and considerable loss of NN , the WMO noted in its annual NN statement . Heat waves resulted in an astounding loss in productivity in 2018 , because it was often either too hot to work or RB VB outside safely . An incredible 153 CD hours of labour were wiped out last NN due to heat waves , nearly three times more than 2000 , according to the 2018 report of the Lancet Countdown on NN and NN NN released November 28 . The most recent El Niño event ended in CD , and it was associated with catastrophic coral bleaching on the Great Barrier Reef , severe droughts in Africa , South NNP and parts of the Pacific and southeast Asia , and wildfires in Indonesia and Canada . While the current El Niño is not expected to be as severe , it MD still bring dangerous NN to vulnerable areas IN the NN , NNS warn . El Niño and its opposite , La Niña , form a natural cycle that can last from a few months to CD or three NNS . When they occur , NN patterns IN the NN can be affected , producing a range of impacts on crop yields , famine , heating , and cooling demands of homes and buildings , fire risks , coral bleaching , and extreme NN . Researchers VBP the impacts of El Niño / La Niña events have become more severe over the past 20 NNS due to a warmer NN . This is akin to an athlete on steroids who takes stimulants during the Olympic final . The combination of JJ - caused NN and a natural upswing in NNS increases the odds that any JJ El Niño NN will be the warmest ever , VBD NN scientist Michael Mann from Pennsylvania NNP NNP . Mann co-authored a 2018 NN linking NN NN to the recent run of record - breaking droughts , heat waves , wildfires , and flooding events in the northern hemisphere . These destructive NN extremes will increase 50 percent on average and MD increase as much as 300 percent due to NN NN alone unless the NN acts quickly to cut NN NNS from burning fossil fuels , the NN concluded . Normally , El Niño events bring heavy rains to California , and if that happens this winter it MD lead to flash flooding and mud slides after wildfires burned 1.6 CD acres this autumn , VBD Stevenson . Nearly 14,000 homes were destroyed in those fires and now the JJ storms of the season have already produced flooding and mud slides . While El Niño brings rain and cooler NN to the southern U.S. , it brings heat and drought to Australia , as well as dry winter conditions in southeastern Africa and northern Brazil . Catastrophic wildfires have already broken out in eastern Australia , along with a heat wave with NNS over 44 degrees C ( 111 degrees F ) at the end of November . As JJ NN continues future El Niño events will likely result in RB cooler and wetter conditions in the U.S. , enhancing flood risks . Meanwhile , La Niña events will increase wildfire danger and drought in the southwestern NNP NNPS , Stevenson VBD . While the impacts of El Niño / La Niña events are amplified in a warmer NN , it ’s not VBN whether NN NN will affect the occurrence or strength of these events in the future , she VBD . La Niña and El Niño are , respectively , the cold and warm phases of the El Niño - Southern Oscillation ( ENSO ) cycle , which regulates heat in the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean . In conditions defined by climatologists as " neutral , " high air pressure predominates in the eastern Pacific , while low pressure predominates in the west . The difference in pressure generates the trade winds , which blow east to west over the NN of the tropical Pacific , pushing the warm waters westward . The deeper , cooler waters then NN in the east , replacing the warm waters .
